**Commentary on the *Awakening to Reality***

**Title:** *Commentary on the Awakening to Reality*. Three fascicles. Originally attributed to Xiangchuan Wumingzi (Weng Yuanming), i.e., Weng Baoguang, of the Southern Song period. Base text from the *Daoist Canon of the Zhengtong Era*, *Dongzhen* section, *Jade Instructions* category.

**Preface to the Commentary on the *Awakening to Reality***

The Master once said to me: The Perfected One of Tiantai Mountain, having attained the Dao, received from the Supreme Emperor the title "Purple Yang Perfected." In silent service to the imperial house, he often concealed or revealed himself in the world, yet none recognized him.

In his youth, he studied alongside my ancestor at the Imperial Academy. Though he did not pass the examinations, he was endowed from birth with a numinous root. While perusing Buddhist scriptures, he suddenly experienced the awakening of the bamboo-striking insight, instantly realizing non-arising and directly transcending into the true emptiness of the pure and tranquil nature-ocean.

In his later years, he encountered the Elder of Qingcheng in Chengdu, from whom he fully grasped the profound principles of the Golden Elixir. He thoroughly understood the mechanism of yin-yang mutual interaction, the principle of heaven and earth’s inversion and generation, and thus was able to cultivate reality and restore life, ascending into formlessness. Embracing the One and illuminating the mind, he attained perfect emptiness and quiescence.

Thus, his form and spirit were both wondrous, merging with the Dao in truth. His transformations were boundless, manifesting universally throughout the dharma-realm. Through this marvelous function, he broadly delivered the deluded.

Even now, those who encounter the Way of nature and life are truly rare.

During the Yuanfeng era, he propagated the Buddhist Dharma alongside Liu Fengzhen’s disciples. Before entering quiescence, he left behind a gatha on non-arising. After his disciples cremated his remains, they obtained hundreds of relics, some as large as jujubes.

Seven years later, his disciples arrived at Wangwu Mountain and again met the Perfected One as before. This demonstrated his form and spirit both wondrous, the meaning of nature and life both complete.

The Perfected One harbored a nature of compassion and benevolence, magnanimous and forthright. He exhausted principle and fulfilled nature to reach life, unifying the Three Teachings without distinction in marvelous function. Unwilling to cultivate goodness solely for himself, he composed the *Awakening to Reality* to instruct later learners.

First, he used the Way of immortals and life to entice their cultivation, thus beginning the work with verses on the Golden Elixir’s arts. Finally, he employed the true suchness of empty nature to dispel their illusions, concluding the volume with Chan poems.

The essentials of the Golden Elixir lie in establishing the furnace and cauldron with the true yin of the two eights and true yang. Drawing the primordial qi into this furnace and cauldron, it transforms into a grain as large as a millet seed, called the "Great One Containing Reality."

Thus, he first composed fifteen seven-character quatrains to represent the number of the two eights’ true yin and true yang. One five-character poem represents the single grain of the Great One.

After obtaining this grain and returning it to the cinnabar field, one then circulates the fire, following the sequence of the sixty-four hexagrams. Hence, he composed sixty-four quatrains corresponding to the sixty-four hexagrams of the *Zhouyi*.

The fire-circulation practice lasts ten months, with bathing periods totaling twelve months. He added twelve *Xijiangyue* poems to correspond to the annual cycle of the celestial revolution.

When the ten months of practice are complete, the embryo is perfected and transforms into pure yang qi. Thus, he composed a total of eighty-one regulated verses, symbolizing the pure yang number of nine nines.

After the form transforms into qi, one then embraces the Origin for nine years, refining qi into spirit, and merging spirit with the Dao. Thus, form and spirit become both wondrous.

Wondrous yet formless, spirit merges with the Dao, profound and unfathomable. Here, life and nature both reside in the ultimate source of emptiness and quiescence. Therefore, he concluded the volume with the Chan Way of nature.

Thus, the work first presents the great principles of the Golden Elixir in this sequence. The oral instructions on medicinal substances, fire phases, and secret formulas are all embedded within the verses; readers may seek understanding through the text.

After its transmission spread widely, discrepancies and errors multiplied in the texts. Only the version preserved in the family of Lu Sicheng, grandson of the Duke of Longtu, is authentic—this being the edition personally transmitted by the Perfected One. The Perfected One also provided a detailed preface on his attainments at the end of the volume.

While traveling through the grotto-heavens, I obtained this authentic text and corrected its errors. Only then did I comprehend the Perfected One’s intent in composing the work, its sequence of chapters, and its symbolic representation of the Golden Elixir’s methods.

Though his words are concise, their principles are comprehensive; though his allusions are subtle, their analogies are intimate. Truly, this is the authentic guide for later learners and the essential compendium of the scriptural canon.

Nowadays, scholars often pursue heterodox and irrelevant paths to verification. Some recklessly misinterpret texts like *Celestial Court’s Supreme Treasure*, *Jade Flask Golden Elixir*, or *Primal Spirit Marvelous Elixir*, yet none attain the deep roots and firm foundation of true cultivation.

There was also Ye Wenshu, who used the numbers of the Great Ultimate and the Great Extension to explain and analyze the text. He appended diagrams at the end, calling it the *Outer Transmission of the Awakening to Reality*. This is like mistaking a curtain’s shadow for a horse or a screen’s silhouette for qian—trifling with the true scripture and increasing learners’ doubts.

Alas! The Perfected One once said:
*Not realizing one’s own errors,*
*One teaches others the wrong path,*
*Leading them astray in the sea of delusion for kalpas—*
*How can such heartless deception be endured?*
Was he not referring to Wenshu?

How could he know that a single grain of the Golden Elixir is the primordial qi of the Great Ultimate? The sage borrows the substances of the two eights, gathering their qi in a single moment to transform it into a grain. Ingesting it, one immediately ascends to sagehood.

The Perfected One said:
*Within a single time-period, the elixir is complete.*
And again:
*Swallowing a grain of Golden Elixir,*
*One realizes my life is not decreed by heaven.*
How could these be empty words?

Wenshu, failing to grasp this principle, mistakenly rejected the "single moment." If it were not a single moment, would it not require three years or nine? Yet the Perfected One spoke of "a brief moment’s effort yielding eternal ease and boundless joy."

He also misconstrued the "single grain" as a daily elixir, wrongly citing Zhenyizi’s saying of "consuming one grain per day."

Yet if three years or nine were required, one would need to consume over a thousand grains—how could the Perfected One have deceived others with his words of "a single moment"? From these two points alone, it is clear that Wenshu failed to grasp the art of the Golden Elixir. Thus, his reckless annotations abound in errors, unaware that the numbers of the Great Ultimate and the *Dayan* are in fact the timing for firing and symbolic representation. To seek the supreme Dao of the Golden Elixir through symbols is like invoking rain by painting dragons or sating hunger with drawn cakes—how could it not be difficult?

Though dull-witted, I follow the Perfected One’s footsteps. Having received the true response, I dare not forget it day or night. How could I sit idly by while red and purple distort the vermilion, unable to expand the Perfected One’s meaning and clarify it? Thus, unafraid of heavenly retribution, I boldly reveal the celestial mechanism. Faithfully adhering to my master’s secret instructions, I annotate the true text, dividing it into three volumes:

The **upper volume** speaks of the art of strengthening the army to conquer the belly, thereby harvesting the gold.
The **middle volume** expounds the method of enriching the nation and pacifying the people, thereby firing the furnace.
The **lower volume** reveals the Dao of the immortal embracing the One, thereby entering the primordial form.

Each explains its practical matters without the slightest omission. For those of like mind, it will be clear and evident, directly verifying the supreme Dao without being misled by heterodox schools or crooked streams.

**Preface by the Nameless One**

**Annotations on the *Wuzhen Pian*, Volume One**
*Commentary by Weng Yuanming of Xiangchuan*

In refining the Golden Elixir, one always begins at the first moment of the Mid-Autumn Festival, when the first yang stirs. Seated firmly at the *kuigang* position, ascending three tiers of the altar, one grasps the Dragon on the left to stabilize the cauldron’s string and seizes the Tiger on the right to refine the qi’s timing. One civil, one martial, they contend and battle at the Mysterious Gate. One departing, one arriving, they fiercely struggle at the Gate of the Female. Breath aligns with the clepsydra’s marks, the count matches the celestial cycle—no deviation by a hair’s breadth, no regret over the slightest error. Thus, in a brief moment, three battles conclude, and the Elixir Pearl is instantly seized and ingested. Hence, it is called the art of strengthening the army to achieve victory.

The "battle" is the union; the "army" is the Dragon and Tiger. Obtaining the Golden Elixir within a single time-period is the art of conquering the belly. Thus, the *Western Florescence Scripture* states: *"The ultimate victory of strengthening the army lies in the cultivation of the Mysterious Pearl."* Therefore, the Perfected One first presents twenty-eight seven-character verses to clarify the numbers of the Dragon and Tiger, and one five-character verse to signify obtaining a grain of Golden Elixir in a single time-period. This is why I have made it the upper volume—to elucidate the meaning of strengthening the army to achieve victory. The workings of harvesting the Golden Elixir are thus brilliantly clear.

**Fifteen Quatrains in Seven-Character Verse**

Not seeking the great Dao, one strays from the path—
Even with worthy talent, how can one be a true man?
A hundred years of light pass like a spark from stone,
A lifetime’s existence floats like a bubble on water.
Chasing profit and rank for glory and display,
One disregards the body’s withering and decay.
Try asking: can mountains of gold piled high
Ever buy back what is eternally gone?

What men value most in the world is wealth and nobility—these are what all desire. Thus, people of the world exhaust their nature and destiny, fulfilling their lifelong ambitions, competing to pursue them with zeal. Observing their motivations, they are nothing more than indulgence in profit, rank, sensuality, and beauty—truly the spears and halberds that slay life, the shackles that bind the body. Why is this? Because worldly people, ignorant of the heart of virtue and power or the greatness of nature and destiny, only covet profit and rank, daily indulging in delusion, drowning in the river of love, adrift in the sea of desire. Right and wrong, self and others, wage war in their breasts; joy and anger, sorrow and happiness, ravage their bodies. Thus, corpse-demons shorten their years, cold and heat consume their complexion. Unaware, they live a fleeting life, like a flash on water’s edge; a hundred years of light pass in an instant, like a spark from stone. Even if one amasses gold by the bushel and jade by the mountain, when the time comes, can one buy back the body, preventing it from becoming a nest for ants? Alas! Before life’s end is announced, the spirit has already entered another shell. As the True Lord of Empty Serenity said: *"Unenlightened in this life, one enters another shell, cycle after cycle, unaware."*

Alas! Rather than casting oneself into a different species, why not abide in the great Dao? If the Dao is attained and the work completed, the body transcends the azure heavens, riding clouds and qi, driving flying dragons, roaming the boundless, forever unchanged in oneself, bearing the title of Perfected One—this is the season of a true man’s fulfillment, the day of utmost joy and glory. But those entangled in mundane affairs, their hearts mired in dust, falling into the world’s net—even with the worthy talent of Confucius and Mencius, or the splendor of Su and Zhang—are no more than wandering souls on earth, shadowy ghosts of walking corpses. How can they be called true men? Thus, the Perfected One first chants this poem, addressing those of exceptional insight, that they may awaken from a single word, swiftly seek the great Dao, escape the path of delusion, and engage in the work of non-action—only then is one a true man. All else is unworthy.

Though man’s life may span a hundred years,
Longevity or early death, success or failure—none can foreknow.
Yesterday, one rode through the streets on horseback;
Today, one lies in a coffin as a sleeping corpse.
Wealth and wife are left behind, no longer yours;
The sins one carries will follow—who can deceive themselves?

Man’s longevity or early death, success or failure, wealth or poverty, nobility or lowliness—all are silently determined by one’s inherent allotment. How can they be measured or foreknown? Man’s lifespan is roughly a hundred years; even seventy is rare. With a fragile body of limited years, one toils endlessly after the boundless—is this not laborious? With a single breath gone, one departs forever, destination unknown. Is this not a great sorrow?

Thus, one who but yesterday rode a horse through the streets may today lie as a sleeping corpse, with no certainty that the outgoing breath will return. At such a moment, though one may have held the highest rank, enjoyed ten thousand bushels of emolument, possessed priceless treasures, or kept a beauty who could topple cities—all must be cast aside, reduced to nothing, no longer one’s own. The only companion that cannot be deceived and must accompany one is the karma of sins committed in life. Hence the saying: “A thousand things will not go with you; only karma follows the body.”

Master Cao’s verse declares:
*Alas, the toil and turmoil of human life—*
*Like a burning house, the dusty world entangles day by day.*
*Suddenly, the three-inch breath in the throat is cut,*
*And spirit, soul, and consciousness scatter and dissolve.*
*Though wife and children wail and plead in vain,*
*A thousand cries, ten thousand calls—none will turn the head.*
*No matter how shrewdly one schemes in life,*
*Lying in the barren mound, the wise man is lost.*
Truly, these are words of truth.

The great elixir is not sought in vain when encountered. For those who wish to escape the wheel of rebirth and not fall into the snares of the world, nothing surpasses the golden elixir of the great medicine as the sacred ladder to ascension and the swiftest path to transcendence. The Way is most simple and easy; even the dullest and most ignorant, if they practice it, may at once ascend to the rank of the sages. Yet the highest sages guard it in secrecy, forbidding careless disclosure. It is transmitted only through oral instructions to the worthy, never recorded in writing—thus, though difficult to encounter, it is easy to accomplish. Without diligent seeking and earnest resolve, with sincerity that moves the highest heavens, scarcely one or two have ever attained it.

Xie Ziran, longing for this Way’s rarity, yearned for a true master on Penglai. With utmost sincerity, he emptied his coffers, prepared a boat, and, heedless of the perilous waves and vast deeps, set forth without fear. Moved by his devotion, the sea god spoke: “The weak waters of Penglai stretch thirty thousand leagues; not even a mustard seed may float upon them. Where do you think to go?” He directed him instead to Master Sima Ziwei, who dwelt on Red City Mountain. Turning his boat, Xie sought out Red City and indeed found Ziwei, who transmitted the Way to him. After but a few years of cultivation, he ascended to heaven in broad daylight. Ah! Sincerity issuing from within evokes response without—nothing is beyond reach. If one can set the heart and establish resolve thus, how can the Way of the golden elixir fail to be achieved? The Way does not betray man; man constantly betrays the Way.

As the *Cantong Qi* says:
*The Way is neither distant nor near—*
*It is entrusted only to the worthy.*
Without steadfast sincerity and ardent longing, how can one encounter it? To encounter it and not refine it is utter folly.

The secret essentials of the golden elixir are indeed hard to come by. Those who do encounter them possess innate immortal bones and the profound hidden virtue of their ancestors. Moreover, one must command great wealth and gather three companions to accomplish this principle. The enlightened know this well, though it is difficult to express. Thus, when Wang Chongzhao met Master Haichan and received the Way of the golden elixir, lacking the means to begin, he journeyed to Luoyang to seek the aid of Lords Han and Fu. With their support, he attained the Way and departed. If one encounters this Way and finds capable companions of one mind to cultivate together, yet refuses to act, such a one is truly the most foolish of fools.

The Immortal Elder’s poem to Master Liu says:
*I hear you have known the medicine for many years—*
*Why not gather your heart and refine the lead?*
*Let not the candle be blown out by the wind,*
*For in the six paths of rebirth, heaven cannot be blamed.*
These words speak truly.

To learn immortality, one must learn the immortality of heaven. Immortals are of several ranks: those whose yin spirits are most numinous yet formless are ghost immortals. Those who live in the world free from illness and sorrow, enjoying long life, are human immortals. Those who soar through the air and walk through mist, neither hungering nor thirsting, unharmed by cold or heat, roaming the sea isles and living forever without death, are earth immortals. Those whose form and spirit are both wondrous, merging with the Dao in truth, who cast no shadow when walking in sun or moon, pass through metal and stone without hindrance, transform endlessly, now old, now young, now hidden, now manifest, now present, now gone—gathering to form a body, dispersing to become qi—whose depths the milfoil and tortoise cannot fathom, whose mysteries even spirits and gods cannot know, are heaven immortals.

Thus, Master Yin Zhen says: Those who can extinguish desire, cultivate embryonic breathing, move the spirit, shed the husk, enter samadhi, and cast off the corpse, relying on yin to be born without decay, are lower-grade immortals. Those who receive the talismans of the Three Armors, the covenant of the Great One, the scriptures and methods of the Three Caverns of Highest Clarity, or the arts of the sword and corpse-liberation, and thereby attain the Way, become immortals of the Southern Palace, dwelling in the various grotto-heavens as middle-grade immortals. Those who refine the great medicine of the golden elixir and attain the Way, ascending bodily to heaven, become the supreme, limitless, highest-grade heaven immortals.

The Immortal Elder exhorts those who cultivate the truth to establish a resolute and extraordinary resolve, sever all distracting thoughts, concentrate the spirit, and delight in non-action. Rejecting the lesser and middling immortals, they should aspire to realize the supreme, limitless, highest-grade heaven immortal. Only the golden elixir is the most authentic path.

Among the seventy-two grades of elixirs, the Way to learn heaven immortality is simple and easily accomplished—only the golden elixir, the supreme Way, is most authentic. This is the creation of something from nothing, not the later-born five metals, eight stones, cinnabar, mercury, black lead, white tin, yin and yang, arsenic, autumn stone, or herbs and trees of the world, nor the fluids, essence, qi, blood, and humors of the body—all of which are the creation of something from something. It is the primordial qi of the undifferentiated chaos before heaven. By methodically gathering and refining it within a single two-hour period, it coalesces into a grain the size of a millet seed, called the golden elixir, also known as true lead, yang elixir, true mercury, true unity essence, true unity water, water-fire, or the true qi of the Great One. When ingested, it instantly elevates one to the rank of the sages. This is the highest examination, the wondrous Way of heaven immortals, rarely heard of in the world.

When the two substances meet, nature and emotion unite; where the five phases are complete, tiger and dragon coil. The true unity qi emerges before heaven and earth, blending within the formless void—dim and indistinct, profound and obscure, invisible to sight, inaudible to hearing, untouchable by grasp. How then does it condense into a grain the size of a millet seed?

The sage gives form to the formless through the substantial, manifests the invisible through the visible. That which is substantial and takes form is true yin and true yang. These formless, kindred substances—void and nonexistent—are the primal qi of the crescent moon’s first phase, possessing qi yet lacking substance. When the two take shape in relation to one another, a single entity arises: this is the true unity qi, coalescing into a millet-seed pearl.

As the scripture says: *"The primordial single treasure-pearl resides within the empty mystery, vast as a millet grain."* This is its proof. Fearing the leakage of celestial secrets, the sages used true yin and true yang as metaphors for the crescent qi of the Green Dragon and White Tiger, or likened them to true lead and true mercury.

In the verses of the immortals, the dragon is further named the Crimson Dragon, the Thunder Dragon, the Celestial Soul, the Qian House, the Qian Crucible, the Jade Tripod, the Fusang, the Jade Pool, the half-moon of the lower crescent, the Eastern Yang, the Eldest Son, the Vermilion Mercury, the Cinnabar Tripod, the Li Sun, the Scarlet Phoenix—all variations of the Green Dragon’s single name. The tiger is likewise called the Black Tiger, the Dui Tiger, the Earthly Soul, the Kun Position, the Kun Tripod, the Metal Tripod, the Metal Crucible, the Hua Peak, the half-moon of the first crescent, the Western River, the Youngest Daughter, the Black Lead, the Crescent-Moon Crucible, the Kan Moon, the Black Tortoise—all variations of the White Tiger’s single name.

The dragon’s crescent qi is named the Alchemical Maiden, the Wood Mercury, the Azure Maiden, the Vermilion-Ensheathed Mercury, Emotion, the Yellow Sprout, the Flowing Pearl, the Green-Clad Maiden, the Golden Crow, the Li Maiden, the Female Dragon, the True Fire, the Sixteen-Year-Old Alchemical Maiden, the Jade Mushroom, the Wood Fluid—all one and the same. The tiger’s crescent qi is called True Lead, the Metal Duke, the Metal Essence, the Metal in Water, the Silver in Water, Nature, the Golden Flower, the White Snow, the White-Clad Gentleman, the Talisman Water, the Nine-Three Gentleman, the Jade Hare, the Kan Son, the Male Tiger, the Knife-Tip—all one and the same.

When the two substances meet and nature and emotion unite, these two substances are the dragon and tiger. The Green Dragon in the east belongs to wood, which engenders fire; the dragon’s crescent qi, as fire, is Emotion, belonging to the south, called the Vermilion Bird. The White Tiger in the west belongs to metal, which engenders water; the tiger’s crescent qi, as water, is Nature, belonging to the north, called the Dark Warrior. Dragon-wood, tiger-metal, nature-water, and emotion-fire constitute the four images, gathering at the central palace to return their merit to wu and ji, thereby forming the elixir. The elixir is earth. These are the true five phases, hence it is said: *"When the two substances meet, nature and emotion unite; where the five phases are complete, tiger and dragon coil."*

Originally, with wu and ji as the matchmakers, husband and wife are thus made to harmoniously unite. The Wood Dragon in the east and the Metal Tiger in the west are separated—how can they be made to unite and generate transformation? The matchmaker is the Yellow Dame. Only by driving the dragon with the left hand and steering the tiger with the right can they be made to merge. The dragon and tiger, east and west, are brought together by the Yellow Dame; without her matchmaking, how could they be joined as husband and wife in joyful union?

Now, when the true unity qi is stirred and coalesces into the golden liquid returning elixir, this is truly the image of the external medicine. Only after the work is accomplished and one ascends to the Jade Palace, enveloped in ninefold radiance, does one ride the auspicious simurgh. After ingesting this golden elixir, there remains the labor of ten months to refine form into qi, followed by nine years of embracing the one to transform qi into spirit. When both form and spirit attain perfection and merge with the Dao in truth, one rides the simurgh and crane through the ninefold radiance to ascend and pay homage at the Jade Palace.

This method is true within the true, wondrous beyond wonder—all because I alone differ from others. This Way is most divine, most sagely, most simple, most easy, most noble, most exalted, profound beyond profundity, wondrous beyond wonder, rarely heard of in the world. The immortal transcends his kind, rises above the multitude, and alone grasps its profound meaning.

Immortal Chongzhao said: *"Of all the Daoists in the world, none can be commended for the Way of the Golden Elixir—only Pingshu alone."* He is Mount Tai, the river and sea; how dare the mere streams and puddles presume to compare?

Knowing that inversion arises from li and kan, who recognizes the floating and sinking to determine host and guest? Li is yang and resides in the south, yet is called female—outwardly yang but inwardly yin—termed true mercury. Kan is yin and resides in the north, yet is called male—outwardly yin but inwardly yang—termed true lead.

The immortal said: *"The sun dwells in the li position yet is called female; the moon pairs with the toad palace yet is male. If you do not grasp the meaning of this inversion, do not presume to discourse on such lofty matters with shallow understanding."* This speaks of kan’s male and li’s female, like the father’s essence and the mother’s blood, the sun’s crow and the moon’s hare, mercury within cinnabar and silver within lead. It also refers to heaven’s Yellow Son and earth’s Dark Maiden. All these point to the crescent qi of the first phase.

Host and guest: yang, noble and elevated, resides on the left as the host; yin, humble and low, resides on the right as the guest. Li is fire, which flames upward, sharing wood’s nature of floating—both belong to yang, hence the host. Kan is water, which moistens downward, sharing metal’s nature of sinking—both belong to yin, hence the guest.

This is the natural order of the common Dao. Yet now li is reversed to become female, kan reversed to become male; the host is reversed to become the guest, and the guest reversed to become the host—is this not inversion? Thus it is said: *"Only when one knows inversion through li and kan / Who discerns floating and sinking to fix host and guest?"*

To fix host and guest is to take the crescent qi of the two phases as the inverted host and guest, not the host and guest of the common Dao—hence they are called host and guest.

The golden crucible seeks to retain cinnabar-wrapped mercury,
The jade pool first descends with silver in water.
The golden crucible: gold is a yin substance, yet within the crucible resides yang qi—this is the image of yin containing yang, the White Tiger. The jade pool: jade is a yang substance, yet within the pool resides yin qi—this is the image of yang containing yin, the Green Dragon. Mercury within cinnabar is the crescent qi of the dragon.

If the cultivator of the elixir wishes to use the tiger to retain the dragon’s qi, they must first drive the dragon to the tiger. Only then will the two qi intertwine, their natures harmonizing. Through refinement and firing, the true essence of the One naturally congeals.

Fire, moreover, is the untransmitted marvel of the sages. At its highest, it reaches eighty-four thousand *li*; at its lowest, it stirs even in the depths of the North Pole’s great abyss. When kindled, it becomes fire—thus the sage uses it to complete the elixir, while the fool invites disaster.

The divine work of firing does not last the whole morning—
A single wheel of sun emerges from the deep pool.
Fire here refers to the crescent qi of the two phases, the beginning of a day. *Zi* is the origin of the six yangs, hence called "morning" or "sun at *zi*." When the sage moves the elixir-fire with divine skill, in less than half an hour, the true essence of the One is obtained—a grain like millet, appearing in the Northern Sea, its light piercing the curtains, like a single blazing sun rising from the deep pool. It is not the whole morning, for within one hour, the golden elixir is instantly achieved. This describes the external medicine’s symbolic form.

The tiger leaps, the dragon soars—waves surge, winds roar;
At the central true position, the Mysterious Pearl is born.
Fruit ripens on the branch in due time,
The child in the womb—how could it be different?

This verse speaks of the true essence of the One, whose creation lies outside—called the golden elixir, true lead, or true earth. When swallowed into the five viscera, it becomes the yang elixir. Here, the tiger is the golden elixir. The dragon is one’s true qi. The wind and waves are the qi surging from the primordial sea, its turbulence like waves, its motion like wind. The "central true position" is the golden womb’s divine chamber within the elixir, where the elixir coalesces. The Mysterious Pearl is the infant, also called the golden liquid returning elixir.

The golden elixir is formed from the primordial chaos before heaven and earth, thus it is the mother, the sovereign, the lead—called the tiger. One’s true qi, born after heaven and earth, is the child, the minister, the mercury—called the dragon. When the golden elixir enters from without and is swallowed into the abdomen, one’s true qi rises from the lower sea of qi like wind and waves, converging eagerly—like a minister attending the sovereign, a child longing for its mother. Their mutual affinity is evident. When dragon and tiger unite in the divine chamber’s earthen cauldron, the sacred embryo forms—no different from fruit ripening on the branch or a child in the womb. After ten months, the embryo matures, and the spirit naturally emerges through transformation.

The Southern and Northern lineages reverse the hexagrams’ images;
Morning and evening firing align with the celestial pivot.
"South and North" refer to the *zi* and *wu* hours; "lineage source" means the critical beginning. "Morning and evening" pertain to the principles of day and night. *Zi* is the head of the six yangs, hence "morning," corresponding to the *Zhun* hexagram’s duty—this is the time for advancing fire. *Wu* is the source of the six yins, hence "evening," corresponding to the *Meng* hexagram’s duty—this is the time for advancing water. Each day, two hexagrams govern their duties, beginning with *Zhun* and *Meng*, ending with *Jiji* and *Wei*, cycling endlessly—hence "reversing the hexagrams’ images."

The *Cantong Qi* states: *"At dawn, *Zhun* governs its duty; by dusk, *Meng* takes its turn. Day and night each have one hexagram, used in proper sequence. From *Jiji* to *Wei* at dusk, the end returns to a new beginning."*

Each day, two hexagrams govern their duties, along with the four hexagrams of the male and female, totaling sixty-four hexagrams in a month. Each hexagram has six lines, so sixty-four hexagrams comprise three hundred eighty-four lines, corresponding to the days of a year including intercalary months. *Qian*’s first nine begins with *Kun*’s first six; *Qian*’s count is thirty-six, so six lines total two hundred sixteen. *Kun*’s first six begins with *Qian*’s first nine; *Kun*’s count is twenty-four, so six lines total one hundred forty-four. Together, they sum to three hundred sixty, the degrees of a celestial cycle.

The movements of the sun and moon—conjunction, ascent, descent—do not exceed the bounds of the hexagrams’ lines. The moon moves swiftly, completing one celestial cycle in a month. The sun moves slowly, completing one cycle in a year. The "celestial pivot" is the pivot of the Dipper. Each day and night, it completes one cycle, shifting position once a month. For example, the first month aligns with *yin*, the second with *mao*.

Take the first month aligning with *yin*: if the sun has not yet passed the official division, *yin* is placed over *hai*, reaching *you* to find *zi*—this is the first month, with the Dipper’s handle pointing to *you*, marking the true *zi* hour. If the sun has passed the official division, *yin* is placed over *xu*, reaching *yin* to find *wu*—this is the first month, with the Dipper’s handle pointing to *yin*, marking the true *wu* hour.

The superior adept, the perfected person, understands the waxing and waning of the sun and moon, the ascent and descent of yin and yang. They practice the *zi-wu* firing with day and night, adjusting numbers according to the Dipper’s position, naturally aligning with celestial degrees—hence "aligning with the celestial pivot." The marvel of the supreme Dao lies herein.

One must know that great reclusion resides in the marketplace;
Do not seek solitude in the deep mountains.

The great elixir of golden cinnabar is possessed by every household, unbound by marketplace or court. Yet how many recognize the dragon when they see it, or the tiger when they meet it? How few reverse their practice to cultivate it! In but a moment, a precious pearl coalesces, large as a grain of millet. Held in the palm, it radiates iridescent light. Swallowed into the belly, the jeweled palace is renewed.

The great Dao hides in the marketplace—those in the mountains know not. How could those of solitary yin and scant yang ever grasp this Way? The yellow sprout and white snow are not hard to find; the enlightened must rely on deep virtue and conduct. The Four Symbols and Five Phases all depend on earth: the dragon’s latent *qi* is called the yellow sprout, the tiger’s latent *qi* is called the white snow. The root of the great elixir truly lies here.

The Way is most simple, the matter not distant. Yet without great merit and mighty deeds, none may encounter a true master to transmit its profound essentials. This origin begins in emptiness and gives birth to the One *qi*; the One *qi* transforms into yin and yang, called dragon and tiger. The dragon, wood, engenders fire; the tiger, metal, engenders water—wood, fire, water, metal: these are the Four Symbols. The Four Symbols unite to form the elixir, and the elixir’s completion depends on earth. Earth has no fixed form; it divides its position among the four directions and four seasons. Without earth of the four seasons, the four sequences do not proceed, and the myriad things do not arise. Thus the Four Symbols and Five Phases all depend on earth.

How could the Three Origins and Eight Trigrams depart from *ren*? *Ren* is water, the true One *qi*. The true One *qi* is the true One water, born before heaven and earth, transforming into the yang dragon and yin tiger. When dragon and tiger unite, the elixir is formed. The elixir is earth; the dragon is wood; the tiger is metal. Metal, wood, and earth are called the Three Natures, and the Three Natures are the Three Origins. The Three Origins do not depart from the transformation of the true One water.

The Eight Trigrams: the One *qi* first transforms into heaven, called *qian*, the father. Next it transforms into earth, called *kun*, the mother. *Qian*, with its yang *qi*, seeks *kun*’s yin *qi*: at the first seeking, it gives birth to the eldest son, *zhen*; at the second seeking, the middle son, *kan*; at the third seeking, the youngest son, *gen*—this is *qian*’s yang *qi* uniting with *kun*’s *qi* to give birth to the three yang. Then *kun*, with its yin *qi*, seeks *qian*’s yang *qi*: at the first seeking, it gives birth to the eldest daughter, *xun*; at the second seeking, the middle daughter, *li*; at the third seeking, the youngest daughter, *dui*—this is *kun*’s *qi* uniting with *qian*’s *qi* to give birth to the three yin. These too do not depart from the transformation of the true One *qi*. Hence it is said: “How could the Three Origins and Eight Trigrams depart from *ren*?”

Not only the Three Origins and Eight Trigrams do not depart from the true One *qi*. Since the opening of heaven and earth, all things with form and name arise from this and transform. The True One Master said: “The essence of the true One is the mother of heaven and earth, the root of yin and yang, the origin of water and fire, the ancestor of the sun and moon, the source of the Three Powers, and the progenitor of the Five Phases. The myriad things rely on it for birth and completion; the thousand spirits depend on it for joy and sorrow. As for the lofty heavens and profound earth, the grottoes and famous mountains, the mysterious images and numinous spirits, the immortals, buddhas, worthies, and sages, the winds and rains, the dark and bright moons, the spring, summer, autumn, and winter—before any sign appears, all arise from this leaden *qi* and transform.”

For those who cultivate the elixir, if they obtain the true One water, then all matters are complete. The refined numinous essence is hard for others to recognize; when all yin demons are dissolved, ghosts dare not approach. Swallowing the true One millet into the cinnabar field and circulating the fire for ten months burns away all the host of yin. The body transforms into a pure yang immortal, and the yin demons, corpse-ghosts, flee without refuge.

Should one wish to leave secret formulas among humankind, none have met a *ziqi*—how could one find another like oneself? The yellow lead must be sought with intent; let not the days slip by in vain. Simply capture the earthly *po* to seize the vermilion mercury, and the celestial *hun* will naturally restrain the watery metal. This may be called: “When the Dao is lofty, dragons and tigers submit”; it may be said: “When virtue is weighty, ghosts and spirits revere.”

The true lead is the golden elixir, the primordial One *qi*, akin to the bright moon, now full, now crescent, sharing its origin with the river tides and the lunar palace. The earthly *po* is the external medicine—the white tiger. The internal medicine is the golden elixir. The celestial *hun* is the external medicine—the green dragon. Internally, it is the body’s own vermilion mercury; externally, it is the dragon’s latent *qi*. Internally, it is the golden elixir, also called silver in water. This speaks of the internal and external medicines.

When the sun has passed one’s fate, then life follows in extinction. We must seek a master with intent, swiftly refine the golden elixir, and transcend life and death. Simply capture the tiger’s soul, and the dragon will naturally restrain its *po*. The two *qi* swallow each other and produce the golden elixir. Once the golden elixir is obtained, use this elixir to capture one’s true mercury; the true mercury transforms the golden elixir and completes the sacred embryo.

When the true dragon and true tiger within are subdued, the mundane dragon and mundane tiger without naturally submit. When the gods, spirits, ghosts, and *po* within the body are sanctified, the obstructive ghosts and stagnant spirits beyond the world bow in reverence. None but those of abundant Dao and flourishing virtue can achieve this.

Once you know your life spans as heaven and earth, afflictions can no longer arise in the heart. The body transforms into pure yang, its longevity matching heaven and earth, roaming beyond the mundane while dwelling freely in the world. All thoughts dissolved, afflictions cannot touch the heart.

Cease refining the Three Yellows and Four Spirits; seeking herbs and plants is even further from the truth. Yin and yang of the same kind return to mutual resonance; the two eights in balance naturally unite in affinity.

The Three Yellows, Four Spirits, minerals, metals, herbs, and plants are all post-celestial turbid substances—how could they transform the formed into the formless? Thus, the *Scripture of Western Florescence* states: "External flesh cannot form the embryo; stitched flowers cannot bear fruit."

The qi of True Unity arises before heaven and earth, profound and unfathomable, beyond measure. Through the union of the two eights—substances of the same kind in perfect balance—they bind and intertwine in mutual resonance, stirred into manifestation.

"Same kind" refers to the emotion within non-emotion, the color within non-color—like eight ounces of crow’s liver and half a catty of hare’s marrow.

When the sun glows red at the bottom of the pool, yin demons vanish; when the moon shines white atop the mountain, the medicinal sprout is renewed.

The pool’s yin and the sun’s yang: the red sun at the pool’s bottom is yang within yin. Yang within yin is pure yang, devoid of yin qi, so yin demons perish—this is the tiger’s initial infant qi, called red lead. The white moon atop the mountain is yin within yang, the dragon’s initial latent qi, called black mercury.

The sage takes these two substances, refines them in a single hour into a grain of yang elixir, which coalesces in the Northern Sea, blazing like the sun, its light piercing the curtains. At once, it is drawn into the abdomen to ignite one’s yin mercury. The yin mercury—all the body’s yin and perverse qi—is entirely consumed, just as when the dawn sun rises from the Eastern Sea, its radiance dispels all demons.

One’s own yin mercury, from the summit of the lower peak of the cinnabar field, newly receives the qi of the yang elixir, gradually congealing and sprouting tenderly—hence the "new medicinal sprout." Like the moon at the first crescent, exchanging light with the sun, it newly receives the sun’s qi at dusk, casting a faint glow on the western mountain’s *geng* peak, shaped like an eyebrow—its light tender, the medicinal sprout renewed. This allegory illustrates the imagery of the internal and external medicines.

People of this age must recognize true lead and mercury—they are not common cinnabar or quicksilver. The *Scripture of Western Florescence* states: "Yin within yang is called the Radiant Maiden; yang within yin is named the Golden Duke." These are the husband and wife within the crucible, the ladder to the Purple Palace. Those who awaken see immortality before their very eyes; those who remain deluded are separated by endless sands of dust.

The external true lead and true mercury are none other than the *qi* of the dragon and tiger at their first crescent. The internal true lead and true mercury are one’s own true *qi*, the golden elixir. Those of this age must recognize the authenticity of lead and mercury—these alone are real; all else is false. These two true substances can transform the corporeal into the incorporeal, becoming true immortals, for the lead and mercury of the mundane world cannot compare.

Not knowing the inversion within the mysterious, how can one plant lotuses in fire? By human affairs, a man cannot conceive, nor can lotuses grow in fire. Yet the immortals possess the wondrous art of inversion, enabling a man to conceive, just as lotuses bloom in fire. Why? The *li* trigram is male, yet here it is female; the *kan* trigram is female, yet here it is male. This is the inversion. When these two are inverted, the elixir is born. Using the elixir to refine one’s own mercury into an infant is a man’s conception—is this not inversion? One who penetrates this principle plants lotuses in fire.

"Lead the White Tiger home to nurture,
And bear a luminous pearl like the full moon."

The Green Dragon and White Tiger are both the essence of the true One, two things divided east and west, yet sharing the same origin under different names. The essence of the true One pertains to mercury; mercury is the dragon, dwelling in the east, so the essence of the true One resides in the east. The White Tiger is originally the child of the true One, born in the west but with its home in the east. The Immortal Elder said: *"The Golden Duke is a child of the eastern house, sent to the western neighbor to be born. Recognize and call him home to nurture, match him with the Radiant Maiden in kinship."*

Thus, leading the White Tiger home to pair with the Green Dragon as husband and wife, they produce a luminous pearl, round like the moon. The method of elixir refinement begins by taking the half-moon at the western upper crescent, obtaining eight ounces of yang metal. Next, take the half-moon at the eastern lower crescent, obtaining half a pound of yin water. Combining these two half-moons’ *qi* gives birth to the elixir, round like the full moon. The *Fire Record of the Great Elixir* states: *"A single grain of numinous elixir, large as a millet seed, weighs one pound."* These two eight-ounce measures combine into one pound, echoing the Immortal Elder’s meaning of the full moon—both metaphors for the imagery of the external medicine.

Once this elixir is swallowed, the golden elixir becomes the White Tiger. Lead this White Tiger into your abdomen, pair it with your own mercury, then circulate the yin tally and yang fire through the sixty-four hexagrams, refining it into the golden liquid returning elixir. A single grain also weighs one pound, round like the moon—this is the imagery of the internal medicine.

The internal medicine’s roundness like the moon arises from the fire-circulation hexagrams: each hexagram has six lines, sixty-four hexagrams total three hundred eighty-four lines, symbolizing one pound and three hundred eighty-four *zhu*. The external medicine’s roundness like the moon comes from the two half-moons of the upper and lower crescents’ eightfold numbers. The *Kinship of the Three* states: *"The upper crescent *dui* is eight, the lower crescent *gen* is also eight; when the two crescents merge their essence, the body of *qian* and *kun* is complete. Two eights make one pound, the Dao of Change stands firm."* True One said: *"The upper and lower crescents form the number of one pound. The three hundred eighty-four lines correspond to the fire phases—this is the calculation of lines."*

The Immortal Elder’s indication of the full moon’s meaning is to make scholars thoroughly understand the principles of creation, distinguishing the internal and external eightfold numbers—they cannot be discussed indiscriminately.

Do not idly guard the elixir furnace to watch the fire phase;
Simply settle the spirit and rest the breath, letting nature take its course.
When all yin is stripped away, the elixir matures,
Leaping from the mortal cage to live ten thousand years.

The fire is not the common fire of the world but the primordial ancestral *qi* of original yin and yang. There is no elixir furnace to guard—this is merely a metaphor. Qingxiazi said: *"The crucible is no metal crucible, the furnace no medicinal furnace. Fire arises from below *li*, water responds within *kan*. When the three natures unite, the two flavors naturally converge. The embryo is sealed without leakage, transformation occurs in an instant."*

Gao Xiangxian said: *"Heaven and earth bind the union of man and woman; the four images and five phases interlock. Day and night alternate in *zhun* and *meng* by natural law—why laboriously watch the fire phase?"* This speaks of the natural furnace fire, not the furnace fire of the world. Simply settle the spirit and regulate the breath, harmonizing civil and martial, timing the tally and clepsydra—do not err by even a fraction, and within half an hour, the elixir will be attained. Then, follow the timing to advance and retreat the yin tally and yang fire, applying the techniques of drawing and adding, guarding against danger. After ten months of work, all yin is stripped away, the body transforms into pure yang, leaping from the mortal cage—how could this be merely ten thousand years?

This is merely a rough outline; only here is the golden liquid returning elixir achieved, yet it has not yet entered the wondrous. Further embrace the One for nine years, returning *qi* to its root, unifying form and spirit in wondrous harmony, merging with the Dao in truth.

To know the source of the medicinal stream,
It lies only in the southwest—its native land.
The *Scripture of Western Florescence* states: *"The medicine is born in the southwest, gathered in *wu* and *ji*; seize the moment, and the day to work arrives."*

The southwest is *kun*, the birthplace of the tiger. This direction is also where the moon rises, hence its native land. The moon is the crystal of metal and water; the upper and lower crescents’ metal and water merge *qi* to generate the medicine. The source of the medicinal material is the earth’s productive stream, truly issuing from the Mother *kun*.

When lead sees *gui* born, hasten to gather;
When metal meets the full moon’s distance, it is no longer fit to taste.
When lead sees *gui* born, the moon is full. When metal meets the full moon’s distance, the moon wanes. Seizing or missing the moment depends on oral transmission—it lies in heart-to-heart instruction.

An ancient poem says:
*"Count the breaths of the celestial cycle, tally each moment;
The jade clepsydra’s drips echo in perfect accord."*
This is the esoteric oral transmission passed from mouth to mouth.

Lu Sicheng, in his *Postface to the Awakening to Reality* as the Immortal Elder, noted that many who transmitted this poem misread *lead* as *if* and *metal* as *like*, gravely distorting the Immortal Elder’s profound intent. *Metal* and *lead* are none other than the Golden Elixir. On the *gui* day at the *zi* hour, one must work without delay—this is the moment to swiftly gather. If one waits until past the full moon, it is no longer fit to taste. This is the celestial mechanism, the oral transmission of the secret; it cannot be committed to writing. Master Lu revealed its threads to correct the errors of the foolish and ignorant. Yet he guarded its source, fearing its spread through written records. We who have received the mysterious instruction in person should understand it well. If not, it remains as unattainable as a pearl suspended five *zhang* above the earth—a millet-grain pearl not easily obtained.

Alas, how many stray paths abound! Many mistake cinnabar for lead and gold, treating the gathering of *tian gui* as child’s play. Ye Wenshu’s talk of *kun* receiving *gui* is laughable. All these are the reckless fabrications of those who have never met a true master.

*"Return it to the earthen crucible, seal it tightly;
Next, let the flowing pearl pair and match."*

Ingest the elixir into the Yellow Court’s earthen crucible, firmly sealing the embryo to prevent leakage. Circulate the fire, let the flowing pearl enter the mercury, and pair it with the embryo to coalesce into the numinous.

*"The medicine weighs one *jin* and requires two eights;
Harmonize the fire’s timing, entrusting it to yin and yang."*

Eight ounces of crow’s liver, half a *jin* of hare’s marrow—two eights together make one *jin*, hence the medicine’s weight. The fire is not fire in truth but borrows the qi of yin and yang, harmonizing and applying it to succeed.

*"Though ten thousand scrolls of immortal scriptures speak alike,
The Golden Elixir alone is the root and origin.
Follow the *kun* position to form the body;
Plant it in the *qian* household’s Chamber of Mutual Resonance."*

Do not wonder that the celestial mechanism has been fully revealed—it is only that scholars remain deluded. If one can grasp the poem’s meaning, one stands among the Three Pure Ones as a Supreme Lord.

The ten thousand scrolls of immortal scriptures all converge on one truth: the qi of the waxing crescent (two eights) is the essence of the Elixir. Simply follow the generative principle of the Mother *kun* and cultivate it in reverse. After obtaining the Elixir, plant it in the Father *qian*’s Chamber of Mutual Resonance to circulate the fire of the tally. The wonder of elixir refinement lies in nothing but the two words *lead* and *fire*. The Immortal Elder has here disclosed the entire celestial mechanism, yet scholars remain stubbornly deluded. Why not seek it within oneself to illuminate the Supreme Way, coalescing into a single millet-grain and ascending as a guest of the Emperor?

*"In plants and trees, yin and yang are equally paired;
If one is lacking, they will not flourish.
First, the green leaves open as yang takes the lead;
Later, the red flowers bloom as yin follows."*

This is the constant Way of daily use, yet who knows the true source’s return to the root? I say to all gentlemen who study the Dao: if you do not understand yin and yang, do not scoff in ignorance.

Before plants and trees sprout, they contain the purest essence. When their husks split, they receive the primal qi to germinate, thus sending forth a single stem to symbolize that qi. Next, they divide into two leaves to symbolize yin and yang. Then, from between the two leaves, they send forth a bud to correspond to the Three Powers. Beyond this, branches proliferate, flowers and leaves flourish—spring’s green leaves arise, summer’s red flowers bloom, all through the agency of yang qi. Autumn’s solemnity yields fruit, winter’s desolation returns them to mulch, all through the agency of yin qi. When yin and yang are equally paired, transformation is ceaseless; if one is lacking, the myriad things cannot arise.

Master True Unity said: *"Solitary yin does not grow on its own; solitary yang does not achieve completion."* Thus, heaven and earth embrace, and the myriad things transform into purity. Male and female unite in essence, and the myriad things are born. The common people take this as their daily constant Way, unaware of the wondrous principle of the true source—the mechanism of reversing yin and yang, their inverted mutual use—to transcend life and death. If scholars do not understand this and mock me, they merely reveal their own blindness.

*"Three, five, one—just these three words;
From ancient times to now, those who truly understand are rare.
East’s three and south’s two together make five;
North’s one and west’s four share the same."*

Three, five, and one are none other than the dragon and tiger. The dragon pertains to wood, wood’s number is three, and it resides in the east. Wood generates fire, so the dragon’s crescent qi is fire. Fire’s number is two, and it resides in the south. The two things share a source, so three and two combine to form five. The tiger pertains to metal, metal’s number is four, and it resides in the west. Metal generates water, so the tiger’s child qi pertains to water. Water’s number is one, and it resides in the north. The two things share an office, so four and one combine to form five. The two fives meet in the central palace of *wu* and *ji*, which pertains to earth, earth’s number is five, forming the three fives. The three fives combine to generate the Elixir, and the Elixir is one. These three words—from ancient times to the present—are understood by few. Those who do comprehend them coalesce the infant, a truly rare achievement.

*"The infant is one containing true qi;
After ten months, the embryo is complete, and the foundation of sagehood is laid."*

One is the Elixir, and the Elixir is the infant. One is the true qi of Unity, the mother of heaven and earth. My true Unity is the child of heaven and earth. Drawing in the mother qi to return to the five viscera, it subdues the child qi—like a cat seizing a mouse to prevent its escape. Thus, the qi of mother and child entwine within the embryo to coalesce the infant of Unity, hence the term *Great Unity containing the true*. Containing the true qi of Unity is like a woman carrying a child: after ten months, the gestation is complete, and the sacred embryo is naturally born. Likewise, after ten months of work, the elixir is perfected, and one naturally becomes spiritually sagely—hence the saying, *"After ten months, the embryo is complete, and the foundation of sagehood is laid."*

Do not take solitary yin for possessing yang—cultivating but a single element only leads to emaciation and decline.
Straining the body with presses and stretches is not the Way; refining qi and ingesting mist are all madness.

Within yang lies yin essence—this is one’s true essence, and it is One.
Essence generates qi, qi generates spirit; the nourishment and defense of the whole body originate from this.
When the oil is exhausted, the lamp goes out; when the marrow is depleted, the body perishes.
This speaks of essence and qi as the very root of the body. Yet how can this substance, which belongs to yin—like cinnabar containing mercury, or fire born within wood—be controlled? Its nature is to flee, easily lost and difficult to capture, refusing to be refined. Without the primal yang elixir of Great Unity to subdue it, there is no way to congeal it into transformation. If one cultivates only this single element, one only grows weaker. Moreover, straining the body with presses and stretches is not the true Way, and those who ingest mist and refine qi are but madmen.

Even if one were to absorb the essence of sun and moon, illuminating the five viscera; circulate the twin passes along the spine to replenish the brain and return essence; achieve liberation from the corpse or enter deep meditation—though there be a thousand methods and ten thousand techniques, they all amount to cultivating but a single element. Solitary yin without yang is like a sparrow or hen brooding an egg: can it ever hatch a chick?

Master Zhongli said:
Tears, saliva, fluids, essence, qi, blood, and humor—these seven are all yin.
If one takes such things as the substance of the elixir, how can one’s spirit ascend to the Jade Capital?

Within the body, not only is true essence a yin substance—all five viscera and six bowels are yin, not yang. If this is so, can one truly divide heart and kidney into Kan and Li, or take liver and lung as dragon and tiger? Can one use spirit and qi as mother and child, or cling to fluids as mercury and lead? If one clings to such methods in seeking the proof of pure yang, it is like adding ice to cold or hot water to heat—like making turtles fly and snakes dance, only growing more perverse.

*The Kinship of the Three* says:
Place two women in the same chamber, their beauty most fair; send Su Qin to mediate and Zhang Yi to broker, their eloquence unbounded, their words most persuasive. Though they pour out their hearts to harmonize, seeking to unite as husband and wife, their hair will rot and their teeth decay before they ever know one another.
To wed a woman to a woman, to refine yin with yin—why then bind and strangle? How can transformation and life arise?

The world seeks in vain to subdue mercury and lead—when will they ever see dragon and tiger descend?
I urge you to exhaustively seek the source of your birth, to return to the root and revert to the origin—this is the King of Medicines.

The true tiger and true dragon are the two eights.
The true lead and true mercury are the qi of the two phases.
This Way is most simple, most near, most immediate—yet scholars cling to perverse interpretations, stubbornly recognizing only side doors. They do not know their own kind, vainly seeking mercury and lead. How could they know that the immortal elders directly point to the very source of mercury and lead, the riverhead from which they spring? Exhaust the root of your body—whence you came, where life is established—and in reversing this, returning to the source, the true dragon and true tiger will descend of themselves, the true lead and true mercury will be subdued of themselves. Who but the King of Medicines could achieve this?

In recent times, some have likened the minor elixir of Primordial Unity to the golden elixir—like grasping at the moon by climbing bamboo, is this not far from the mark? All that is born after heaven and earth, possessing form and substance, is not the supreme medicine. For that which lies below form is not the Way of the primordial.

Not recognizing true lead as the true ancestor, all efforts are wasted.
The essence of true lead lies in the two eights—all else is not the true Way. Since it is not the true Way, all effort is in vain.

Severing ties with one’s wife, vainly separating yin and yang—
*The Song of Breaking Delusion* from Yimen says:
Solitary yin is not the Way; yin and yang lose their proper places.

Master Wang said:
The student stubbornly rejects wife and concubine, not understanding the effortless and the all-pervading.

Gao Xiangxian said:
Some dwell in solitary yang, some in lone yin.
This speaks of partial yin or partial yang, of cultivating but a single element, of clinging to bedroom arts and the control of women—slandering the immortal Way, leading one far astray.

Fasting only leaves the intestines empty—
*The Song of Breaking Delusion* says:
Severing the root is not the Way; the dead become hungry ghosts.
Truly, these are words of truth.

Herbs, trees, gold, and silver are all coarse substances; mist, clouds, sun, and moon belong to the realm of obscurity.

Even with breathwork and visualization added,
All remain far from the work of the Golden Elixir.

This song speaks of the postcelestial, earth-born, coarse substances—
easy to encounter, hard to perfect.
How could they be mentioned in the same breath as the Golden Elixir?

A five-line verse to mirror the singularity of the Great One:

The maiden dons robes of blue,
The young lord wraps himself in white silk.
The maiden dons robes of blue—
the maiden is the yang’s latent yin, the dragon’s string-qi,
yang within yin, thus called “maiden,” also named “Wood Consort.”
Born of the Azure Dragon, she wears blue.

The young lord is the yin’s latent yang, the tiger’s string-qi,
yin within yang, thus called “Golden Lord.”
Born of the White Tiger, he wraps himself in white silk.

To see is not to use; to use is not to see.
What has form and can be seen belongs to the postcelestial, earth-born, coarse substances.
Because it has form, it can be seen but not used.
What has no form to observe is the first and second string-qi of the primal.
Though unseen, it can be used.

In the dim and indistinct, they meet;
Within the profound and obscure, transformation occurs.
The dim and indistinct, the profound and obscure—
this is the qi of the Primal Unity, born before heaven and earth, beyond measure.
Within the dim lies a thing: the dragon’s first string-qi.
Within the obscure resides an essence: the tiger’s first string-qi.
As the two string-qi dwell in the dim and the obscure—
the essence is the tiger’s string-qi,
the thing is the dragon’s string-qi.
Bound within the dim and obscure, compressed and refined,
the true unity stirs and manifests change—
this is the formless giving birth to form.

In a flash, a flame takes flight,
And the True One emerges of itself.
The True One is the Golden Elixir.
The sage condenses a year’s qi-markers into a single hour,
then divides that hour into six intervals.
Within just two intervals, applying the fire of refinement,
the essence of the true unity is immediately obtained,
coalescing into a single grain of millet,
manifest in the Northern Sea—
is this not the True One emerging in a flash of fire?

This Way is most wondrous.
Without the oral transmission of an immortal master,
who could attain this?

The Immortal Elder thus declares:
Though a single grain of the Golden Elixir arises from the qi of the Great Ultimate,
without the union of the two string-qi, the Elixir cannot form.
The Elixir is earth.
Dragon and tiger, together with the two string-qi, complete the Four Images.
The Four Images converge in the Central Palace to become the Five Phases.
The Supreme Song says:
“The Five Phases are but the medicine;
the Four Images must not be transgressed.”
Thus, the harmony of Five Phases and Four Images gives birth to the Elixir.

These five lines and four rhymes conceal the marvel of the Great One’s primal qi.

*Commentary on the Awakening to Reality, Volume One* concludes.
*Commentary on the Awakening to Reality, Volume Two* begins.

Xiangchuan’s Anonymous Master Weng Yuanming annotates:

The Great Dao of Emptiness and Non-being gives rise to the primal qi;
this primal qi divides into yin and yang.
Thus, the qi of utmost yang—light and pure—floats upward to become heaven;
the qi of utmost yin—heavy and turbid—sinks downward to become earth.
The accumulation of pure yang qi that ascends to heaven is the immortal;
the accumulation of pure yin qi that descends into earth is the ghost.
Endowed with the qi of one yin and one yang, a body neither ascends nor sinks,
dwelling between heaven and earth, may become either immortal or ghost.
Therefore, if one knows the art of cultivation,
stripping away all yin to transform the form into pure yang qi, one ascends as an immortal.
If one knows not cultivation,
daily depleting the original yang to transform the body into pure yin qi, one descends as a ghost.
The *Book of Changes* says: “That which is rooted in heaven inclines upward;
that which is rooted in earth inclines downward.”
Each follows its kind.
Thus, the sage, observing above and examining below,
knows that humans, endowed with the finest essence of heaven and earth,
are the most spiritually noble.
Therefore, they borrow the true yin and true yang,
seizing the primal qi prior to heaven and earth to forge the Elixir,
which they ingest into the qi-sea of the Cinnabar Field,
thereby governing the postnatal qi of the body’s heaven and earth.
Thus, the body’s myriad phenomena naturally return to it,
as the myriad states pay homage to the sovereign,
or the stars encircle the North Star.
Knowing that humans owe their existence to the union of father and mother,
they steal the pure essence of yin and yang as the foundation for transformation,
calling it the "yin tally" and "yang fire."
Circling through the sixty-four hexagrams,
revolving endlessly,
they cycle the seventy-two seasonal nodes and twenty-four qi within a single day and night,
seizing the upright qi of four thousand three hundred and twenty years,
converging it within the qi-sea of the Cinnabar Field.
They nurture the "child pearl,"
which abides in the Central Palace, wu-wei, governing externally.
Thus, externally, it harmonizes the yin-yang tally and fire,
while internally, it generates the true unity of the spirit-body.
After ten months of gestation,
the form transforms into pure yang non-being,
hunger and thirst cannot disturb it,
cold and heat cannot invade it.

The method for enriching the state and pacifying the people:
the state is an analogy for the body;
the people are the essence-qi.
The people are the foundation of the state;
when the foundation is firm, the state is at peace.
If the state lacks a ruler, to whom shall the people turn?
If the ruler lacks ministers, how can the state be governed?
Thus, the sage makes the Elixir the ruler and fire the minister.
When Elixir and fire depend on each other,
ruler and minister rejoice in harmony,
and the world is well-ordered.
When the essence-people are at peace,
the state of the body is enriched.
The *Western Florescence Scripture* says:
“When essence is complete and qi is full, this is enriching the state and pacifying the people.”
This occurs after ingesting the Golden Elixir.
Thus, the Immortal Elder appends sixty-four quatrains to dispel delusion,
arranging them according to the hexagrams of the *Book of Changes*,
to clarify the reckoning of the fire-phase.
He further adds twelve *Moon Over the West River* lyrics,
symbolizing the twelve months of the "bathing" practice.
This is why I divide this into the middle volume,
to elucidate the intent of enriching the state and pacifying the people through the fire-phase.
Such is the proper sequence in the practice of Elixir cultivation.

**Sixty-Four Quatrains**

The radiant Golden Elixir forms in a single day—
the ancient immortals’ words are truly worth heeding.
If one speaks of nine years or three,
it is merely procrastination, delaying the schedule.

The Great Medicine of the Golden Elixir,
with effort no more than half an hour,
yields the Golden Elixir for ingestion.
This "single day" means the sage condenses a year’s qi-nodes into a month,
then condenses a month’s qi-nodes into a day,
and further condenses a day’s work into an hour.
Generally speaking, this is called "a single day."
The Immortal Elder says:
“Exchanging hours for days initiates the divine work.”
Once the Golden Elixir enters the mouth,
one immediately ascends to the sacred realm.
The analogy clarifies how swift the verification is—
how could it take three years or nine,
prolonging time and delaying the schedule?

First take Qian and Kun as the crucible and vessel,
then gather the crow and hare as medicine for refinement.
Once these two are guided into the Yellow Path,
how could the numinous Elixir fail to be born?

An ancient song says:
“The sun and moon are the essence of Qian and Kun;
how could the myriad images and all phenomena not be illuminated?”
The sage uses Qian and Kun as an analogy for the crucible and vessel,
and the sun and moon as an analogy for the medicine.
Moreover, Qian and Kun are the true dragon and true tiger,
while the medicine is the string-qi of dragon and tiger.
Master Wei says:
“The crucible is fundamentally without crucible;
the medicine is fundamentally without medicine.”
The sage borrows names and adopts analogies in this manner.
The essential point lies solely in the initial string-qi of the true dragon and true tiger,
their union and refinement,
so that the essence of true unity congeals within the Central Palace of the Northern Sea.
Thus, the Immortal Elder says:
“Once these two are guided into the Yellow Path,
how could the numinous Elixir fail to be born?”
The Yellow Path is the place of congealment in the Central Palace.

Take the solid center of the Kan position,
to transmute the inner yin of the Li palace.
From this, transform into the vigorous body of Qian,
where hidden flight and leaping are all at the heart’s command.

The Li trigram has outer yang and inner yin;
the Kan trigram has outer yin and inner yang.
Using outer yang to transmute inner yin forms the Qian trigram.
The Metal Mother is the qi of utmost yang,
called the Yang Elixir,
congealed in the Central Palace of the Northern Sea.
Taking it to transmute one’s own yin mercury
transforms it into a body of pure yang.
Thereafter, in firing,
withdrawing and adding, advancing and retreating,
all are at the command of my heart’s operation.
Some mistakenly take the cinnabar of the roundel as the single line in Kan,
but this is as distant as clouds and mud from the Great Medicine of the Golden Elixir.
They do not realize it is a postnatal, impure substance,
not the primal qi of the prior heaven.

If Li and Kan lack Wu and Ji,
though they contain the Four Images, the Elixir cannot form.
Only because each holds the true earth,
does the Golden Elixir achieve reversal and return.

The *Cantong Qi* says:
“Li’s Ji is the sun’s light;
Kan’s Wu is the moon’s essence.”

Li’s Ji resembles the yang qi of the dragon’s bowstring;
Kan’s Wu resembles the yin qi of the tiger’s bowstring.
Wu and Ji are one body of earth,
yet divided between the two forms of dragon and tiger—
thus each holds true earth within.
If dragon and tiger lacked the qi of earth,
how could they merge and draw the Four Images into true earth to form the Elixir?
Only because each contains the qi of earth
do dragon and tiger unite, Wu and Ji conjoin,
the Four Images gather, and the Elixir is achieved—
hence the Way of reversal and return.

The sun dwells in Li’s position yet becomes female;
Kan pairs with the Toad Palace yet is male.
Failing to grasp this principle of inversion,
do not presume to discourse on such lofty matters with mere personal views.
The crow within the sun belongs to yin, thus Li is called female.
The hare within the moon belongs to yang, thus Kan is called male.
To speak without understanding this
is like gazing at the heavens through a tube—
how narrow is one’s vision!

The mercury of the Thunder Dragon emerges from the Land of Li;
the lead of the Lake Tiger is born in the region of Kan.
These two substances arise as children producing their mothers,
and the Five Phases must all enter the Central Palace.
Mercury, the Thunder Dragon, pertains to wood—
wood generates fire, so wood is the mother of fire, fire the child of wood:
this is the ordinary sequence of the common Dao.
Yet when cinnabar, belonging to fire, resides in Li,
mercury is born from within the cinnabar—
fire, contrary to the norm, generates wood,
hence the saying “the child produces the mother.”
The Perfected One of Great White Mountain sings:
*“The Five Phases’ inverted art—
the dragon emerges from within the fire.”*
Lead, the Lake Tiger, pertains to metal—
metal generates water, so metal is the mother of water, water the child of metal:
this is the ordinary sequence of the common Dao.
Yet when black lead, belonging to water, resides in Kan,
silver is born from within the lead—
water, contrary to the norm, generates metal,
hence the saying “the child produces the mother.”
Another song declares:
*“The Five Phases do not proceed in order—
the tiger is born within the water.”*
The Immortal Elder speaks of lead being born in Kan,
not silver, because the silver within lead is called true lead,
also known as silver within water—
thus he refers to true lead, speaking of lead rather than silver.
These two substances mutually generate one another,
forming the Four Images,
which gather in the Central Palace to complete the Five Phases—
the Five Phases unite, and the Golden Elixir congeals.
Thus it is said: *“The Five Phases must all enter the Central Palace.”*

The hexagrams establish images to represent forms;
grasp the image, forget the words, and the meaning becomes clear.
Later generations of deluded disciples cling to these images,
practicing hexagram qi in hopes of ascension.
The hexagrams are but the trap and snare of the firing process.
When Master Wei studied the *Book of Changes*,
he awakened to the fact that the workings of the Golden Elixir
are identical to those of the *Changes*—
thus he composed the *Cantong Qi*,
elaborating the images of the *Changes* to illuminate the Great Elixir,
offering guidance to later generations.
He compared Qian and Kun to the crucible and furnace,
symbolizing the numinous womb within the self’s belly.
He took Kan and Li as the medicinal substances,
symbolizing the lead and mercury within the numinous womb.
Qian and Kun are the parents of all hexagrams;
Kan and Li are the true essences of the parents—
thus these four hexagrams reside in the Central Palace,
just as the numinous womb’s lead and mercury dwell in the Cinnabar Field.
Abiding in the center to govern the exterior,
these four hexagrams are not bound by the revolving hub’s reckoning.
The remaining hexagrams are distributed throughout a single month,
advancing the firing times in sequence—
beginning with *Tun* and *Meng*,
ending with *Ji Ji*,
revolving without cease, like a wheel’s unending motion.
Each day governs two hexagrams,
three days accounting for six hexagrams—
together with the four hexagrams of Qian, Kun, Kan, and Li,
the total is sixty-four hexagrams,
comprising three hundred sixty-four lines,
symbolizing a year’s three hundred eighty-four days, including the intercalary remainder.
They also represent the two times eight ounces of the Golden Elixir,
totaling three hundred eighty-four *zhu*.
All are metaphors and established images.
Thus, the adept who studies these hexagrams
may awaken to the firing’s workings.
Once the firing times are understood,
the hexagrams may all be forgotten as useless.
Yet today’s students, deluded by this,
practice hexagram qi,
wearying their bodies and tormenting their minds in hopes of ascension—
is this not lamentable?
*“Catch the fish, forget the trap;
catch the hare, forget the snare.”*
Now they cling to the trap and snare as if they were the fish and hare—
how far they have strayed from the Dao!

Swallowing saliva and absorbing qi are human practices,
yet only with substance can transformation and generation occur.
If the crucible lacks a true seed,
it is like boiling an empty cauldron with fierce fire.
The so-called practices of swallowing saliva and absorbing qi
are all postnatal substances born of heaven and earth—
not true qi absorption.
True qi absorption first subdues and then absorbs.
*“Subdue qi without absorbing it;
absorb only after subduing qi.
Absorbing qi does not grant long life—
long life requires subduing qi.”*
The qi of the True One
dwells in the unfathomable, the indistinct—
difficult to seek, difficult to perceive.
The sage subdues it with method,
thus within the unfathomable there is substance,
within the indistinct there is essence.
Refining this essence and substance into the Elixir,
absorbing it into the Cinnabar Field,
then the myriad transformations arise.
Thus it is said: *“Only with substance can transformation and generation occur”*—
this substance is the true seed.
Without this true seed,
all efforts are labor in vain,
like boiling an empty cauldron with great fire—
before long, all will be ruined.

On the peaks of Mount Hua, the male tiger roars;
in the depths of Fusang’s sea, the female dragon hums.
The Yellow Dame herself knows how to act as matchmaker,
sending them to become husband and wife with a single heart.
Mount Hua is the western mountain’s image—
the tiger.
The male tiger is the yang qi of the tiger,
yin within yang—
thus it is called the male tiger.
Fusang is where the sun rises from the sea,
symbolizing the dragon.
The female dragon is the yin qi of the dragon,
yang within yin—
thus it is called the female dragon.
These two are separated,
dwelling in the east and west.
The matchmaker, the Yellow Dame,
enables their union as husband and wife,
joining as one heart to produce the yellow sprout.

Harmonizing lead and mercury to form the Elixir,
neither great nor small harms the two realms’ wholeness.
Drive the dragon, and fire-mercury soars;
ride the tiger, and water-lead glitters.

Binding the warp of creation to establish it,
the primordial harmonious qi coalesces—
what harm could there be?
Thus, neither great nor small harms the two realms’ wholeness.

The dragon is great, the tiger small—
this is the principle of yang’s honor and yin’s humility.
If one asks what true lead is,
the toad’s radiance shines all day upon the Western River.
The Golden Elixir arises from the union of upper and lower crescents,
gold and water conjoined—
this is called true lead.
The toad’s radiance is the essence of metal-water,
