belonging to yin.
"Shines" signifies its exchange of light with the sun,
symbolizing the Dao of yin-yang union.
The west is the direction of metal,
precisely aligned with the central qi of the eighth month.
"River" is water.
On the fifteenth day of the eighth month,
the sages sense the fusion of metal and water qi,
giving rise to the essence of the true One—
hence, "the toad’s radiance shines all day upon the Western River."

If one does not recognize the yang essence and the roles of host and guest,
how can one know which is distant and which is near?
In the chamber, sealing the Gate of Tail and Yin Orifice,
how many in Jambudvīpa have been led to ruin?
Zhongli said:
The four great elements of the body all belong to yin—
what then is the yang essence?
This essence is the qi of the true One,
the most yang of substances—
it is called the Yang Elixir.
The true within one’s own body belongs to yin,
serving as the master of the body to nurture its entirety.
The Yang Elixir comes from without,
subduing one’s own yin mercury—
thus, the Elixir becomes the host,
while one’s own mercury becomes the guest.
When the two long for each other,
they congeal into golden cinnabar,
naturally immovable.
Then, with the addition of fire,
they are refined into the Golden Liquid Returned Elixir.
Thus, the Yang Elixir outside is called distant,
while one’s own true qi within is called near.
Reversing this near and far to establish host and guest—
this is how the Dao is accomplished.
Deluded disciples fail to grasp this principle,
instead practicing the arts of bedchamber retention,
forcibly sealing their essence and qi,
calling it "refining the Yin Elixir,"
seeking to prolong life—
as if using kindling to extinguish fire.
The scripture says:
Fire arises from wood,
disaster follows swiftly.
The harm done is grave—
can one not be cautious?

Use lead, but not common lead;
once true lead is used, it is then discarded.
This is the true esoteric formula for using lead—
"Use lead, do not use it" is no empty word.
Common lead is of the postnatal, impure substance.
True lead is the qi of the true One.
A person’s essence and qi scatter daily,
unable to congeal and form the sacred embryo.
Thus, the sages refine true lead to subdue them,
causing them to congeal into cinnabar.
Day by day, fire is applied,
gradually adding mercury.
As mercury qi increases,
lead qi diminishes.
Adding mercury, reducing lead—
such is the marvel.
After ten months, the fire is complete,
the six hundred hexagrams conclude,
lead qi ascends and floats away,
like dust in a bright window,
scattering in fragments.
After nine years of embracing the One,
lead qi is entirely dispersed,
leaving only pure dry mercury.
When lead is exhausted and mercury desiccated,
they transform into the Great Returned Elixir of Golden Liquid.
The body becomes purely yang,
its lifespan equal to heaven’s—
thus, "once true lead is used, it is then discarded."
The phrase "use lead, do not use it"—
how could it be mere fabrication?
Hearing the Dao to this point,
one should enlighten the mind before heaven, saying:
"The teacher’s grace is hard to repay.
I vow to accomplish the Dao to requite the teacher’s kindness.
To betray the teacher is to betray heaven."

When bamboo is broken, it is fitting to mend it with bamboo;
when a chick is overturned, it must be righted with an egg.
All other methods are labor in vain—
how can they compare to true lead uniting with the sacred mechanism?
If a bamboo vessel breaks, can it be mended with metal or wood?
It must be mended with bamboo—
only then is the vessel whole.
If a chick is overturned, can it be warmed with earth or stone?
It must be righted with an egg—
only then will it hatch and live.
Master Tao said:
"When bamboo is severed, mend it with bamboo;
when wood is split, repair it with wood.
A leaking roof is covered with tiles;
a declining person is sustained by their kind."
In cultivating the Dao, without the qi of the same kind,
all effort is wasted labor.
The *Cantong Qi* says:
"With the same kind, effort is easily applied;
with different kinds, skill is hard to achieve.
To become an immortal through ingestion,
one must use that which is of the same kind."
Humans receive the finest qi of heaven and earth to come into being.
True lead is the mother qi of heaven and earth,
conceived through a vessel of the same kind—
thus, true lead is the mother qi,
while one’s own essence and qi are the child qi.
Is this not the ultimate marvel of the same kind?
How can one attain this?
It is the profound mechanism of the sages,
the essential Dao of spontaneity.

Medicine meets its kindred qi and forms an image;
the Dao unites with the subtle and formless, becoming natural.
Swallowing a single grain of the Golden Elixir,
one then knows that my fate is not ruled by heaven.

There is a thing formless yet complete,
born before heaven and earth.
The sages forcibly named it the qi of the Primordial True One.
Invisible when seen,
inaudible when heard,
intangible when grasped.
The sages, through the qi of the two eights’ initial crescent,
sensed and communicated with it,
descending in spirit to form an image.
Within the empty mystery,
a grain like millet—
taking and ingesting it,
one’s own mercury is instantly dried,
transforming into a purely yang body,
its years equal to heaven and earth.
Master Chaoyuan said:
"Life and death are entirely governed by heaven and earth,
yet destiny originally belongs to mercury and lead."
Is this not "my fate lies within me, not in heaven"?

The Dao arises from emptiness and generates the One qi,
from the One qi, yin and yang are produced.
Yin and yang unite to give birth to the Three Bodies,
the Three Bodies give rise to the myriad things.
The Dao is fundamentally empty, yet gives form to the real.
The Dao is fundamentally nonexistent, yet gives shape to existence.
Once shaped, life begins—
one gives birth to two,
two gives birth to three,
three gives birth to the myriad things.
The myriad things all bear yin and embrace yang,
harmonizing through the primordial qi.
Before their form appears,
the primordial harmonious qi is invisible.
Once formed,
the light and clear qi becomes yang,
the heavy and turbid qi becomes yin—
thus, yang heaven is the father,
yin earth is the mother.
The two qi intertwine,
their natures harmonizing,
uniting to form the Three Bodies—
these are the Three Powers:
heaven, earth, and humanity.

The *Book of Changes* states:
"Heaven and earth intertwine, and the myriad things transform into purity.
Male and female unite in essence, and the myriad things are born through transformation."
The sage delves into these profound mysteries to know their source,
exhausts their divine workings to understand their transformations.
Thus, he can return to the root and restore the origin,
inverting and refining, reversing the workings of creation.
He plunders the mother qi of heaven and earth to forge the elixir,
steals the essence of yin and yang as the fire of non-action,
refines the form to return to the One Radiance,
refines the Radiance to revert to emptiness and nothingness.
Thus, body and Dao unite,
subtle and wondrously interconnected,
endlessly transforming,
hidden and manifest beyond measure—
this is called the Perfected Person.

A single flavor from Snow Mountain, fine as ghee,
poured into the crucible of Eastern Yang’s creation.
Snow Mountain, white in color, symbolizes the west—
this is the Golden Elixir.
A single grain of the Golden Elixir,
tastes like ghee.
Take and ingest it,
enter the crucible within my cinnabar field,
refining it into the sacred embryo.

"Should one pass beyond Kunlun to the northwest,
Zhang Qian first meets Ma Gu."
Kunlun Mountain lies amid the sea,
and the Kunlun of my body also rests within the lower watery sea,
its form resembling Kunlun Mountain—
the true place where fire is kindled.
Kunlun Mountain has a gate,
called the Mysterious Gate,
which is the Gate of Heaven.
The Gate of Heaven lies in the northwest, the position of Qian.
The immortal elder says: "Planted in the Qian household’s chamber of union."
Thus, traveling northwest,
Zhang Qian meets Ma Gu.
Zhang Qian symbolizes the Qian trigram,
embodying yang fire,
and also represents true mercury.
Ma Gu symbolizes the Kun trigram,
embodying the yin tally,
and also represents true lead.
This speaks of passing beyond Kunlun to kindle the fire,
entering through the Mysterious Gate—
then within the crucible, true lead first meets true mercury,
and transformation begins.
When the true embryo melts within,
true fire connects without,
Kun’s tally joins Qian’s tally,
yin water pursues the yang tally,
the two fires intermingle,
lead and mercury unite—
the root of the immortals’ Dao lies herein.

Zhang Qian’s ride on the raft,
arriving at the lunar palace to meet the Woman Star,
is but a metaphor for the union of yin and yang.

The Maiden wanders with purpose,
her forward steps short, her backward steps long.
The Maiden is mercury,
said to wander with the fire in a fixed pattern.
The forward step is the work of the outer medicine,
the backward step is the work of the inner medicine.
With these two movements,
her wandering follows its own course.
When the sage first begins the work of refining the elixir,
he moves the mercury fire for no more than half an hour,
immediately obtaining the essence of the True One to ingest—
thus, the forward step must be short.
After consuming the elixir,
he moves his own mercury fire,
requiring ten months of work—
thus, the backward step is long.

Returning, he enters the Yellow Dame’s abode,
marrying the Metal Lord to become the Old Gentleman.
The Yellow Dame’s inner symbol
is the golden womb, the earthen crucible.
The Metal Lord is true lead,
the Old Gentleman symbolizes pure yang.
True mercury, through the external movement of fire,
flies into the chamber of spirit,
uniting with true lead in mutual embrace,
transforming into a body of pure yang—
thus, she marries the Metal Lord to become the Old Gentleman.
"Returning" signifies the completion of the work.

In use, one must divide the left and right armies—
let them take the lead while I remain the guest.

Advise you, when facing the battlefront, not to underestimate the foe—
lest you lose our priceless treasure of the house.
This clarifies the workings of fire and timing.
The "general" is fire.
The left is civil, the right is martial.
The sage condenses a year’s fire-timing into a single month,
a month’s timing into a single day.
From *zi* to *si*, the six hours belong to yang,
symbolizing the virtue of spring and summer’s growth—
thus civil fire resides on the left, called "yang fire."
From *wu* to *hai*, the six hours belong to yin,
symbolizing the punishment of autumn and winter’s withering—
thus martial fire resides on the right, called "yin tally."
"Let them take the lead while I remain the guest" means
holding to the feminine without clinging to the masculine,
maintaining stillness without contention.
The host is yang and masculine, fond of strife;
the guest is yin and feminine, fond of quiet.
This expresses caution against peril, reverence for danger.
The art of war says: "Wait at ease for the weary,"
and again: "Control others without being controlled"—
this is the meaning.
The application of the Dao lies in fire,
the use of fire lies in the practitioner—
like a guest before the host,
advancing and retreating with reverence,
daring not act recklessly.
Those who work with fire must not fail to understand this.

In applying fire, first set the water clock to divide *zi* and *wu*.
Next, connect yin and yang to establish the foundation of transformation.
Deploy the sixty-four hexagrams within the yin tally,
strike the twenty-four qi with yang fire.
The celestial gate is in hand,
the earthly axis stored in the heart.
Gather the seventy-two seasonal nodes at the crucial ford,
concentrate them within the crucible.
Seize the three thousand six hundred breaths of true qi,
converge them within the embryo.
With methodical application, orderly withdrawal and addition,
movement guarded against peril—
dare not err by even a hair’s breadth.
Thus, externally, one joins the tally of yin and yang;
internally, the body of True Unity is born.
If, however, the mind is not reverent,
the timing and measures deviate,
causing the Maiden to flee,
the numinous embryo within the crucible to fail,
and the priceless treasure of the Returned Elixir to be lost.
Now, facing the battlefront,
how could one not hold to the feminine and underestimate the foe?

The White Tiger of Western Mountain rages wildly,
the Azure Dragon of Eastern Sea cannot be withstood.
Seize them with both hands and force them to fight to the death—
they transform into a lump of purple-gold frost.
This speaks of external imagery,
already explained in the third poem of the previous four stanzas.
The purple-gold frost is the Golden Elixir.
Master Haichan said:
"With the left hand seize the Azure Dragon’s head,
with the right drag the White Tiger’s tail—
swallow them both at once,
and find the taste most sweet.
Count it as gold within water,
only then does one grasp the profound mystery of the subtle truth."
This is the proof.
To take both hands as two beasts is mistaken.

After the first quarter and before the last,
the medicinal flavor is balanced, the qi-image complete.
Gather it and return to the furnace for forging—
refined through nurturing, self-boiling and steaming.
When the moon reaches its thirtieth day,
the yang soul is utterly spent,
the yin essence’s water fills the wheel—
thus it is pure black and without light,
symbolizing the *Kun* hexagram, called "darkness."
At this time, it meets the sun in the two days of darkness and new moon,
moving in union, acting as one.
By the second day, touched by the sun’s light, it conceives,
gradually parting.
By the third day at sunset,
a crescent appears above *geng*—
within the pure yin wheel, one yang light is born,
the soul within the essence arises,
symbolizing the *Zhen* hexagram.
At this moment, the yang soul’s gold is newly born,
the medicinal sprout fresh.
By the eighth day, two yangs arise,
symbolizing the *Dui* hexagram.
At this time, the soul within the essence is half—
level as a cord, called the "first quarter."
Before this quarter belongs to yang, after it to yin—
yin within yang half,
yielding eight ounces of gold within water,
its flavor balanced, its qi-image complete.

By the fifteenth day, three yangs are complete,
symbolizing the *Qian* hexagram.
At this time, the yin essence’s water is exhausted,
the yang soul’s gold fills the wheel—
thus it is full, pure yang without yin,
called the "full moon."
Yang at its peak gives birth to yin—
thus on the sixteenth day, within the pure yang wheel, one yin arises,
the essence within the soul is born,
symbolizing the *Xun* hexagram.
Gradually waning to the twenty-third day, two yins arise,
symbolizing the *Gen* hexagram.
At this time, the essence within the soul is half—
level as a cord, called the "last quarter."
Before this quarter belongs to yin, after it to yang—
yang within yin half,
yielding half a catty of water within gold,
its flavor balanced, its qi-image complete.

The sage gathers these two eights,
captures them in the furnace of creation to boil and forge.
True Unity’s qi transforms into millet grains—
swallowed into the belly,
nurtured and steamed to become the Golden Liquor Returned Elixir.
It wholly relies on yin tally and yang fire,
advancing and retreating, withdrawing and adding—
the slightest deviation, and the Elixir Way is not achieved.
The Immortal Elder’s repeated exhortations in this chapter,
urging self-refinement, are profoundly meaningful.

First observe the heavens to discern the Five Thieves,
next examine the earth to settle the people.
When the people are settled and the nation prosperous, then seek battle—
only through victory can one meet the sage.
The Five Thieves:
in heaven, the five planets;
on earth, the five peaks;
among spirits, the five emperors;
among directions, the five regions;
in humans, the five viscera;
in conduct, the five constants;
in things, the five phases, five colors, five qi, five notes,
five metals, five flavors, five grains—
these are the thieves.
The classic says: "Heaven has five thieves—seeing them brings prosperity."
If one can perceive these and practice reversal,
then the cosmos is in hand, the myriad transformations arise in the body.
Examining the earth’s principle, nothing surpasses settling the people—
the people are the state’s root;
when the root is firm, the state is peaceful and the nation prosperous.
The sage takes the body as the state,
essence and qi as the people,
fire as the minister,
the Elixir as the ruler.
If we can personally seize the Five Thieves and practice reversal,
steal yin and yang to transform them,
then the true essence of Unity can be seized,
one’s own yin mercury instantly hardened,
the essence secured...

Qi secured, seek battle and victory is assured—thus fire is deployed without peril.
When the tenth-month work is complete, the embryo sheds its mortal form to become a true immortal child,
hence it is said: only through victory in battle can one behold the sage.

Sun and moon meet once every three ten-day periods,
timing replaces days in the method of divine work.
Defending the city or waging field battle, one knows fortune and misfortune;
adding numinous cinnabar, the crucible fills with crimson.

Great Yin and Great Yang conjoin once each month—
the sage models this,
condensing a month’s waiting into a single day,
shifting a day’s waiting into a single hour.
When deploying the tally-fire, defend the city and bathe;
when ceasing field assault, dragon and tiger engage in combat.

Divine work is the measure of advancing fire.
Should yin and yang fall into disorder, sun and moon turn perverse,
external fire may move and proceed, yet the inner tally remains still and unresponsive.
Those with the Dao who advance fire and retreat water know fortune and misfortune,
revolving the Dipper and traversing the Winnowing Basket in secret accord with celestial degrees—
naturally the numinous embryo circulates in concealment, the divine crucible gains radiance.
The treasured tally of yin surpasses three hundred,
the numinous scriptures of virtue and Dao fill five thousand.
Immortals of past and present, without number,
all attain the true explanation in this place.

The Two Classics govern all scriptures,
serve as the pivot of all masters—
from ancient times to now, those who attain the Dao do so through these.
On the fifteenth of the eighth month, admire the toad’s glow,
for this is when metal’s essence is at its peak.
When the first yang begins to revive,
advance fire without delay.

On the fifteenth day of the eighth month,
precisely when metal and water flourish,
the first yang revives—midnight at the hour of zi.
Inner and outer elixirs, fire-work proceeds in tandem;
no delay is permissible, lest the season be lost.

The gate of the Mysterious Female is rarely known in the world—
fools point to mouth and nose and act in vain.
Though you may practice breath-work for a thousand years,
how can you seize the golden crow and grapple the rabbit?

The classic says: “The gate of the Mysterious Female
is called the root of Heaven and Earth.
Subtle and continuous, its use is never exhausted.”
Wondrous indeed, these perfect words.
The world cannot know this—
without a true person’s instruction, who could comprehend it?

Of late, Ye Wenshu has claimed the space between the two kidneys to be the "Primordial One Cavity," dismissing all other theories—yet this is even more erroneous. How could the Mysterious Female, a dual entity, be reduced to a single cavity? Since the dawn of creation, without these two, how could the myriad things arise? Thus, from them are established the inner and outer elixirs. The sages guarded this secret, naming it the "Crescent Moon Crucible" and the "Suspended Womb Cauldron."

The golden crow is the golden elixir. The golden elixir governs my mercury, like a cat seizing a mouse or a crow grappling a rabbit—none can escape. To mistake the mouth and nose for the Mysterious Female is folly; even after a thousand years of breath-work, one only grows weaker with the rising sun. Do not take the gate of death for the gate of life, nor cling to the gate of life as the gate of death. Only when you grasp the mechanism of killing and its reversals do you perceive that harm conceals hidden grace.

Yin and yang, the Five Phases—following them brings life, defying them brings death: this is the common Dao. How could the mediocre know of the life that arises from non-life, or the supreme compliance born of non-compliance? If you fathom this principle of reversal—harm concealing grace—then even a man may conceive.

The "killing mechanism" is the "mechanism of theft." When the moon hangs as a half-wheel at heaven’s edge, the dragon’s roar and tiger’s howl resound. Now is the time to refine the two eights; within a single *shi* hour, the elixir is complete. The half-wheel of the moon signifies the number eight. The immortal elder reveals that dragon and tiger each possess an eight, combining to form the two eights. The marvelous workings of the Dao all unfold within this single *shi* hour, when the water’s source is utterly pure, possessing qi yet no form.

In a year, there is but one such day. In a day, but one such *shi* hour. Within this hour, six *hou* periods are divided; applying effort for no more than two *hou* completes the golden elixir. The remaining four *hou* serve other purposes. This is celestial mechanics, not recorded on bamboo or silk, but transmitted mouth-to-heart. The immortal elder speaks of it as a single *shi* hour, hence "within a single *shi* hour, the elixir is complete."

Ye Wenshu, failing to grasp this principle, offered reckless interpretations, claiming the medicine forms in an instant rather than requiring the full hour. Bewildered, he groped in the dark with private conjecture—how laughable! If not for this single hour, would it not become a protracted schedule? How then could it be supremely simple and effortless?

Wondrous indeed! This Dao is not something one may hear of in the mortal world.

According to Nan Guizi’s *Record of the Fire of the Great Elixir*: "I have observed that when the sage begins the work of foundation and the initial refinement of lead, he steals the qi of the Three Origins and the great celestial cycle, seizing the 20,736,000 primordial qi. Gathering them in the cauldron of Qian and Kun, assembling them in the chamber of life and death, he exhausts the numbers of heaven and earth, the numbers of sun and moon, the numbers of dragon and tiger, the numbers of generation and completion, the numbers of yin and yang and the Five Phases. Capturing all in a single *shi* hour, he refines a single grain of sacred elixir, as large as a millet seed yet weighing one *jin*, most numinous and sagely, most exalted and noble. It is the primordial essence of heaven and earth, the sovereign of the body. Truly, he steals from heaven and earth, steals from yin and yang, holds the cosmos in his hand, engenders the myriad transformations within his person, and becomes a perfected immortal, a guest of the Supreme Emperor. Thus, my immortal teacher’s words—'within a single *shi* hour, the elixir is complete'—are no empty speech; this is the proof."

Fire is born of wood, yet its edge lies hidden; without skillful drilling, do not force the attack. Disaster erupts from this—harming oneself. To master it, seek the Golden Duke.

The classic says: "Fire is born of wood, but disaster arises from mutual conquest. Essence resides in the body, yet when emotion stirs, it must dissipate." Without skillful drilling, this harms oneself.

Master Lü says: "The fire burns the seven gates—seal them tightly, lest it scorch the River Chariot’s path. To master it, you must rely on the Golden Duke." The *Cantong Qi* states: "To restrain it, the yellow sprout serves as the root."

Setting up the crucible and establishing the cauldron follows Qian and Kun. Tempering the essence refines the po and hun. Gather the scattered to weave transformation; how dare I entrust such mysteries to mere words?

Accumulated yang qi forms heaven, which, though above, does not moisten below. Accumulated yin qi forms earth, which, though below, does not blaze upward. Thus, heaven and earth do not interact. Without interaction, how can the myriad things be born? Though heaven is the most yang of things, it contains a qi of yin, enabling it to descend to earth. Though earth is the most yin of things, it contains a qi of yang, enabling it to ascend to heaven. When these two qi intertwine, the myriad things transform and mature. Through their interaction, change and transformation arise.

The Dao of the golden elixir—setting up the crucible, establishing the cauldron, tempering the essence to refine the hun and po—all emulate heaven and earth. The *Song of the Mother and Child* says: "When emotions interact, no medicine is needed; when qi harmonizes, no words are spoken." The golden elixir takes qi as its kind, binding it to engender transformation. Beginning from non-being to being, then from being back to non-being, its transformations are endless. This is celestial mechanics—how dare I prattle on, risking the fault of careless disclosure?

The thunderous fire of Kan refines the metal-water phase. Fire erupts from Kunlun, yin and yang conjoined. When these two substances harmonize, the medicine ripens, and fragrance suffuses the body.

The "thunderous fire of Kan" is the fire within water, called the "yin tally," the bowstring qi of the tiger. The "metal-water phase" is the Qian position of the northwest, which is the dragon. The west is also the Gate of Heaven, called the Mysterious Gate. Here, the tiger’s fire within yin refines the Qian dragon. The dragon then stirs the fire of Kunlun in response. When the two fires merge, the essence of the True One naturally congeals. Harvest and ingest it at once, and the hundred bones are all ordered—fragrant and delightful.

The *Cantong Qi* says: "When golden sand enters the five viscera, mist scatters like wind and clouds. Steaming and permeating the four limbs, the complexion becomes joyful and radiant."

The temples turn black, and new teeth regrow.
The old man reverts to youthful vigor, the aged woman becomes a radiant maiden.
Is this not the true fragrance suffusing the body?

After ingesting the elixir, circulate the fire of the yin-yang tally.
The tiger refines the Mysterious Gate with the fire within yin, while the dragon stirs the fire of Kunlun in response.
When the two harmonize, the Golden Liquor Returned Elixir naturally ripens with fragrance, suffusing the body with radiance—fragrant and delightful.

The poem speaks of the inner and outer elixirs’ symbolic resonance:
*To keep the Valley Spirit ever undying,*
*Rely on the Mysterious Female to establish the root.*

When true gold returns to the Yellow Gold Chamber,
a single orb of radiant light abides forever.

The *Book of Changes* says: "What is unfathomable in yin and yang is called the numinous."
The formless responds and thus communicates—like an echo in a valley—hence the "Valley Spirit."
The spirit arises from qi, and qi is born of essence.
Essence generates qi, qi generates spirit.
Thus, spirit and qi govern the body, while the body serves as the vessel of spirit and qi.
Without form, spirit and qi cannot live; without spirit and qi, form cannot stand.
These three depend on one another to engender life.

To attain longevity, rely on the Mysterious Female.
Once the root is established, immortality may be achieved.
All things are born of these two, and by these two they die.
They are the root of Heaven and Earth, the ancestor of the Five Phases,
the stem of yin and yang, the foundation of the myriad transformations.
The sage uses them to refine the outer elixir and relies on them to complete the inner medicine.
Thus, the essence of the True One returns to the Yellow Gold Chamber,
manifesting as a single orb of numinous light.
The body transforms into qi, qi into spirit—
form and spirit both perfected, merging with the Dao in truth,
hidden and revealed beyond measure.

The Three Powers plunder one another’s sustenance;
the Dao secures immortality by concealing this mechanism.
When the myriad transformations are at peace, all concerns cease,
and the hundred bones are ordered, verifying non-action.

Heaven and Earth plunder the myriad things through the four seasons,
hence flourishing and withering without perpetual bloom.
The myriad things plunder humans through the five flavors,
hence life and death without perpetual longevity.
Humans plunder the myriad things through the Five Phases,
hence decay and renewal without enduring existence.

When the Three Plunderings are harmonized and the Three Powers settled,
there arise prosperity and decline, life and death,
flourishing and withering, day and night,
coming and going, emergence and submergence,
decline and rise, self and other,
right and wrong—endlessly arising in cyclical flux,
the natural Dao.

If one can unify these Three Plunderings, reverse their mechanism, and seize it,
defy the seasons to consume them,
then the hundred bones are ordered, the myriad transformations at peace.
When the myriad transformations are at peace, all concerns cease.

*When negativity and positivity first meet, the myriad things flourish;*
*When difficulty and simplicity receive the hexagram, life and completion are bestowed.*

Grasp the meaning here—do not seek mere images.
To exhaust the lines is but to weary the mind.

The solstices of winter and summer mark the origins of yin and yang,
while the hours of midnight and noon are the pivots of day and night.
The sage moves the tally of yin and the fire of yang,
aligning with the Dao of Heaven and Earth, the ascent and descent of yin and yang,
the principles of the sun and moon’s movements.
Gathering the four seasons, eight trigrams, seventy-two pentads, and twenty-four qi,
they array them within the crucible to form the body of the True One.
The principle is simple, the effort unburdensome—
no reckless action is permitted, hence the reliance on hexagrams.

Within the three ten-day periods of a month,
the mystery is expounded, and the fire’s application clarified.
The lines and images are but fishing traps.
*Difficulty* and *Simplicity* are the first of the hexagrams,
symbolizing the inception of fire’s movement and creation’s endowment.
Thus, *Difficulty* governs the morning, *Simplicity* the evening—
the work of qi passes thus.

As for the ascent and descent of Heaven and Earth’s yin and yang within the four seasons:
At the spring equinox in the second month, yang ascends to the center of Heaven and Earth,
yin and yang equally balanced, neither cold nor hot but temperate—
hence the *Peace* hexagram, like the waxing moon’s climate.
Here, yin and yang qi naturally merge,
and the sage does not advance the fire—this is called "bathing."

At the autumn equinox in the eighth month, yin descends to the center of Heaven and Earth,
again yin and yang equally balanced, neither hot nor cold but cool—
hence the *Stagnation* hexagram, like the waning moon’s climate.
Here, yin and yang qi also naturally merge,
and the sage does not advance the water—this too is called "bathing."

If one grasps the meaning within these four hexagrams,
why cling to the lines and weary the mind with laborious thought?
The immortal sage, in compassion, directly points to this shortcut.

As the common saying aligns with the sagely Dao,
one should seek diligently within it.
If one inverts the search in daily use,
the dust of the earth all becomes treasure.

True lead and true mercury are not apart from common speech, everyday words, and daily life.
Inverting their cultivation, the whole earth becomes supreme treasure.

An ancient poem says:
*Day after day, only in your dwelling,*
*Following you daily, yet you remain unaware.*

Heaven and Earth’s fullness and emptiness have their time—
only by discerning their ebb and flow can one know the mechanism.

Since ancient times, the decree of *geng* and *jia* has been proclaimed,
slaying all yin-corpse, the Dao may then be attained.

That Heaven and Earth wax and wane in their seasons—
this is because Heaven and Earth are separated by eighty-four thousand *li*.
At the Winter Solstice, within the center of Earth, a single yang *qi* ascends,
rising each day four hundred sixty *li* and two hundred forty *bu*.
Five days make one *hou*, three *hou* make one *qi*,
three *qi* make one *jie*, and two *jie* make one season—
this is the Spring Equinox.
Counting ninety days, the yang *qi* ascends in total forty-two thousand *li*,
precisely to the midpoint between Heaven and Earth.
At this time, yin holds half of yang, forming the hexagram *Tai*.
Its *qi* transforms from cold to warm,
the time when the myriad things arise—this is spring.

From this point onward, yang *qi* enters the yang position,
ascending as before, gradually reaching the Summer Solstice.
Including the prior count, one hundred eighty days have passed,
and the *qi* has ascended eighty-four thousand *li*, arriving at Heaven.
At this time, yang holds yang, forming the hexagram *Qian*—pure yang.
Its *qi* transforms from warm to hot, thus it is called summer.
The time when the myriad things flourish and reach fullness—thus it is called "waxing."

Now, when heat reaches its extreme, yin arises.
Thus, at the Summer Solstice, a single yin descends from Heaven,
also descending each day four hundred sixty *li* and two hundred forty *bu*.
Five days make one *hou*, three *hou* make one *qi*,
three *qi* make one *jie*, and two *jie* make one season—
this is the Autumn Equinox.
Counting ninety days, the yin *qi* descends in total forty-two thousand *li*,
precisely to the midpoint between Heaven and Earth.
At this time, yang holds half of yin, forming the hexagram *Pi*.
Its *qi* transforms from hot to cool,
the time when the myriad things bear fruit—this is the Autumn Equinox.

From this point onward, yin enters the yin position,
descending as before, gradually reaching the Winter Solstice.
Including the prior count, one hundred eighty days have passed,
and the *qi* has descended eighty-four thousand *li*, arriving at Earth.
At this time, yin holds yin, forming the pure yin hexagram *Kun*.
Its *qi* transforms from cool to cold, thus it is called winter.
The time when the myriad things withdraw and store away—thus it is called "waning."

The waxing and waning of Heaven and Earth are revealed through the moon.
The moon is born from the sun.
On the third day, *Zhen* *geng* takes form;
on the eighth day, *Dui* *ding* completes the crescent.
On the fifteenth day, *Qian* *jia* reaches fullness—
the time when Heaven and Earth wax.
On the sixteenth day, *Xun* *xin* assumes governance;
on the twenty-third day, *Gen* *bing* guards the crescent.
On the thirtieth day, *Kun* *yi* dissolves—
the time when Heaven and Earth wane.

The sage discerns the mechanism of Heaven and Earth’s waxing and waning,
transferring the *qi* and *hou* of a year into a single month.
The first day is taken as the Winter Solstice,
dividing two and a half days into thirty periods to correspond with the month’s *qi* and *hou*.
Thus, on the third day, the moon appears as a crescent upon *geng*.
On the eighth day, the first quarter—yin holding half of yang—
is like the Spring Equinox.
By the fifteenth day, it receives the *qi* of the fourth month’s node,
becoming pure yang; thus, the moon is full.
As the yang *qi* fills the wheel, it is called "waxing."
On this evening, the moon emerges from the *jia* direction.
On the sixteenth day, a single yin arises, gradually waning upon *geng*—
this is the Summer Solstice.
On the twenty-third day, the last quarter—yang holding half of yin—
resembles the Autumn Equinox.
By the thirtieth day, it receives the *qi* of the tenth month’s node,
becoming pure yin filling the wheel—thus it is called "waning."
At dawn on this day, the moon turns toward *jia*,
conjoining with the sun to regenerate yang light,
cycling endlessly.

Moving the yin tally and yang fire,
each following the waxing and waning, ascent and descent of Heaven and Earth,
circulating through the sixty-four hexagrams,
embodying the principle of roundness and waning from *geng* to *jia*,
operating the withdrawal and addition—
this is like a ruler proclaiming decrees.
Thus it is said: "Slaying all yin-corpse, the Dao may be attained."

Ouye personally transmitted the sword-forging method,
matching Ye Stream’s metal and water with softness and hardness.
Once refined, it understands human intent,
slaying evil across ten thousand *li* in a flash of lightning.

Master Ouye forged the sword,
with Heaven and Earth sending a divine maiden to tend the furnace.
It was tempered with metal and water, paired with softness and hardness,
and once refined, it could slay demons and evil—
in a flash of lightning, its numinosity was thus.

The sage’s cauldron-forging is likewise:
taking Heaven and Earth as the furnace,
yin and yang as water and fire,
paired with the Five Phases,
tempered with spirit-*qi*.
Once refined, it can bend or straighten,
soften or harden,
do good or evil,
be round or square.
When the mind conceives a thought, the intent directs its course,
soaring to slay—
in a flash of lightning.
This is the natural divine sword.

If the cultivator of the elixir lacks this sword,
it is like seeking fish and hare without traps and snares.
The immortal sage, borrowing Ouye’s words,
truly speaks of the elusive and formless Mysterious Pearl.

Different names arise from the same source—few know this.
These two mysteries are the essential mechanism.
Preserving life and completing form, clarifying gain and loss,
the purple-gold elixir is most wondrous and numinous.

The scripture says:
"The nameless is the beginning of Heaven and Earth.
The named is the mother of the myriad things."
It also says:
"These two emerge from the same source yet bear different names."
When it is formless, the true one’s *qi* is mercury—
invisible, thus it is the beginning of Heaven and Earth.
When it takes form, the true one’s *qi* appears like a millet grain in the empty mystery—
as lead, it becomes visible, thus it is the mother of Heaven and Earth.
In Heaven, it is called *Li* and mercury;
on Earth, it is called *Kan* and lead.
Their root is the same, yet their emergence differs—
this is called "mysterious and again mysterious."

The superior adept, the perfected one, grasps this dual mystery’s mechanism,
clarifying gain and loss to govern the body.
Then form may be preserved, and life may be safeguarded.
What is called "loss" is the Five Phases in sequence—
the common Dao, where there is birth and death.
What is called "gain" is the Five Phases in reversal—
the elixir body, eternally numinous and enduring.

Alas! The pure yang purple-gold stands at the beginning of Heaven and Earth,
emerges from the mother of Heaven and Earth.
Thus it is said: the purple-gold true medicine is most wondrous and numinous.
One should know the boundless admiration of the former masters.

To empty the heart and fill the abdomen holds profound meaning—
it is but to empty the heart so the knowing mind may settle.
Yet better to first fill the abdomen by refining lead,
then guard and gather the hall brimming with gold.

To empty the heart is to be without self;
without self, the ten thousand dharmas are all void, not a thread stands.
To fill the abdomen is to refine lead and dry mercury;
when mercury dries and form dissolves, it merges with the Dao, becoming formless.
Both principles are wondrous, distinct paths converging as one—
none but the great sage can comprehend this.

To guard and gather the hall brimming with gold
is to tend the essence, qi, and spirit within the body.
The cultivator of truth who has not yet refined lead to dry mercury
has an unfilled abdomen and an unemptied heart—
then nothing can stabilize your essence, and with scant essence,
the returning elixir cannot be completed.

The great medicine’s cultivation may be easy or difficult—
know that it depends on oneself, yet also on Heaven.
If one has not accumulated deeds of hidden virtue,
at every turn, demonic obstructions will arise.
Demonic obstructions lie in Heaven, but cultivation rests with oneself.
Without bestowing hidden virtue, obstacles block every path.

Within blackness, white is the elixir’s mother;
within the male, the female is embraced—this is the sacred embryo.
The Great One in the crucible must be guarded with care;
the Three Fields gather treasures, corresponding to the Three Terraces.

Extracting silver from lead becomes the elixir’s mother;
drawing mercury from cinnabar is the sacred embryo.
These two substances, stirred by the true unity of qi and essence,
congeal within the crucible—only by keenly observing the qi’s timing,
strictly adhering to the method, and allowing not the slightest deviation,
can the three natures converge, coalescing into the elixir-treasure,
aligning above with the Three Terraces.

The eldest son suddenly drinks wine from the west;
the youngest daughter first blooms a flower in the north.
If the Blue Maiden and they meet thereafter,
all at once the lock opens to dwell in the Yellow House.

Zhen represents the eldest son, the Dragon. Dui represents the youngest daughter, the Tiger. The northern land is the yin entity. The "flower of yin qi" is the Tiger’s bowstring qi, called lead-fire. The Blue Maiden is the Alchemical Maiden, the Dragon’s bowstring qi, called mercury-fire. This speaks of the adept refining the elixir, driving the Dragon to approach the Tiger—hence "suddenly drinks wine from the west." The Tiger then opens the yin-gate’s flower to meet the Dragon. When the Azure Dragon’s mercury-fire and White Tiger’s lead-fire unite in love, they seal and converge in the Yellow House, producing the essence of the true One—thus "if the Blue Maiden and they meet thereafter, all at once the lock opens to dwell in the Yellow House."

Within the crescent moon crucible, jade algae arise;
in the cinnabar tripod, mercury levels even.
Only when fire-force is harmonized,
does the yellow sprout gradually grow.

The crescent moon crucible is the yin crucible, containing the yang qi of jade algae—the Tiger’s bowstring qi. The cinnabar tripod is the yang tripod, containing the yin qi of mercury—the Dragon’s bowstring qi. The golden elixir arises solely from the harmonious union of these two bowstring fires. Once balanced, the sprout of the true One takes root in the Yellow House, maturing into a grain of millet.

Dreaming of an audience with Western Florescence, ascending to the Nine Heavens,
I was clearly bestowed the *Zhixuan* scroll.
Its words were few and simple,
only teaching one to refine mercury and lead.

Gao Xiangxian said: Lost in meditation, my soul ascended to Jade Capital. The Lord took pity and commanded Lady Western Florescence to reveal the elixir formula. Its scroll briefly stated:
*"Shu Tong engaged in the work, Wei Boyang led the way,
laughing as they entered the Land of Nothing-Whatsoever.
Following the *Lianshan*, they composed the *Cantongqi*,
leaving it as the eternal sovereign of ten-thousand-generation elixirs."*
Its opening lines read:
*"Qian and Kun are the gates of the Yi,
Qian’s Way is male, Kun’s Way is female.
Yet people know not true yin and yang,
vaguely seeking Dragon and Tiger across the world."*
Though its words are many, it only teaches one to recognize the true Dragon and true Tiger, to refine lead and mercury.

After bathing in the Flowery Pond, the moon’s radiance clears;
riding a golden dragon, I visit the Purple Tenuity.
From then on, after meeting the host of immortals,
tides and valleys shift at will.

The Flowery Pond is the elixir. Once consumed, the work is complete—transformation is divine. The skin becomes like ice and snow, the form graceful as a maiden, the countenance bright as the autumn moon. Riding qi upon clouds, wandering the boundless, I observe the mortal world: seas turn to mulberry fields, mulberry fields to seas.

Without refining the returning elixir, do not retreat to the mountains.
Within and without the mountains, all is not lead.
This supreme treasure exists in every household,
yet people of this age fail to recognize it fully.

The Dragon is not in the eastern sea, nor the Tiger in the western mountains. Every household possesses them. Reverse the process and refine them, and the returning elixir may be attained. The mountains’ yin stillness, inside and out, is not lead—lead is the true yang entity, not distant at all.

Even if one knows cinnabar and black lead,
without knowing the fire-timing, it is as idle as leisure.
The work depends entirely on the power of cultivation;
the slightest deviation prevents the elixir’s formation.

The golden elixir’s transformation relies wholly on the Metal Lord.
The slightest error creates a gulf of a thousand miles.
Thus the sages transmitted the medicine but not the fire.

Do not cling to the elixir furnace and waste effort;
to refine the medicine, seek the crescent moon crucible.
It naturally possesses true fire for nurturing—
no need for firewood, charcoal, or bellows.

Ye Wenshu misidentified the space between the two kidneys as the crescent moon crucible—how mistaken! Unwilling to reflect on his own error, he further misled others with his flawed path. How reckless! This crucible’s mouth opens upward like an inverted crescent, hence its name. It is the Northern Sea, where the primordial ancestral qi resides. Within it dwells natural true fire—what need is there for firewood, charcoal, or bellows?

When the first yang stirs at the time of elixir-making,
the lead tripod warms gently, illuminating the curtains.
At the initial reception of qi, it is easily obtained;
in withdrawal and addition, exercise utmost caution.

When the first yang stirs, it is the position of the *ninth yang*, the hidden dragon. Act swiftly, and the work may be completed in due time—why wait nine years or three? Who knows that at the very beginning of the work, the radiant golden elixir, large as a grain of millet, is gathered into the Yellow Court and nurtured into the supreme treasure?

The lead tripod is the Cavern-Yang Golden Tripod, existing in the void and profound obscurity—it is the natural tripod. Lead is the entity within primordial emptiness. After commencing the work, the lead tripod warms gently, like fire’s attack, like clouds’ spread, harmonizing temperament and suffusing the seas and mountains. If the lead is true, it does not lose its role as the household minister. Thus lead is the ancestral founder, dwelling within the Mysterious Female, the root of heaven and earth. Without tranquility, it cannot be completed; without application, it cannot be obtained—its Way is most wondrous.

"Illuminating the curtains" refers to the radiant essence overflowing during refinement, and after practice, even the finest hairs become visible, revealing the organs within. "Receiving qi" refers to the initial reception of qi, when yin reaches its extreme and yang is born—success lies in receiving qi. "Guarding against danger" refers to the peril in withdrawal and addition. Know its hidden subtleties, weigh them carefully, and do not neglect the timing. In application, guard against danger and do not underestimate the process—hence the risk of withdrawal and addition.

The marvelous qi of heaven and earth follows the *Yi*’s symbolic method. Have you not heard? With a single swing of the *jia*-sword, demonic armies scatter—this is the power of harmony.

The Mysterious Pearl takes form as yang arises;
when yang reaches its peak, yin dissipates, stripping away all form.
After ten months, frost descends and the elixir ripens—
even gods and ghosts must then stand in awe.

The Golden Liquor Returning Elixir, when warmed, takes form. From the winter solstice’s yang hour at midnight, advance the yang fire, thus generating true essence as yang pursues it. From the summer solstice’s yin hour at noon, advance the yin tally, stripping away until the tenth month’s frost-descending time, when the returning elixir finally ripens. Shedding the embryo and transforming into a purely yang Heavenly Immortal, even ghosts are startled and gods submit.

In the months of the Hare and Rooster, at their appointed times,
Punishment and Virtue arrive at the gate—these are the elixir’s symbols.

At this stage, the golden sand must be bathed—
if fire is added further, peril and ruin will follow.
The second month of the Hare is governed by Virtue,
the eighth month of the Rooster by Punishment.
These two months mark the time for bathing,
when fire should cease; if recklessly applied, the elixir will scatter and be lost.

The songs and scriptures expound the truth,
yet never commit the fire-tending to written word.
To grasp the oral secrets that unlock the mystery,
one must discuss them in detail with an immortal sage.
The *Fire Records* span six hundred chapters,
each echoing the last, interwoven and aligned with heaven’s pattern.
What heaven conceals, sages do not transmit in writing—
only when meeting a true master may one proceed, never with haste.

Though your wisdom surpasses Yan and Min,
without encountering a perfected one, do not force conjecture.
For the elixir scriptures lack the oral transmission—
where then can you conceive the numinous embryo?
A thousand classics, ten thousand treatises
but scatter only branches and leaves.
The supreme Way is not complex—
it is transmitted solely as the mind-seal.
Without a true master, even one brighter than Yan and Min
will only speculate in vain, never coalescing the sacred embryo.

To know the method of refining and nurturing the returning elixir,
plant the seed in your own garden.
No need for forced effort or boastful claims—
naturally, the fruit will ripen and the true embryo emerge.
This Way is most near, like sowing in your own garden—
its proximity is self-evident.
To seek what is not of your kind is to stray ever farther.
When kindred forces act, what effort is required?

When the Four Symbols converge, the mysterious body takes form;
where the Five Directions move, purple radiance shines.
The embryo shed, taken into the mouth, the whole body becomes sacred—
countless dragons and spirits silently shudder in awe.
As soon as Dragon and Tiger unite,
the Five Phases and Four Symbols all converge.
At the meeting of Five Phases and Four Symbols,
the true One’s mysterious body coalesces into a grain of millet, glowing purple.
Then, stealthily guiding the Red Dragon,
seize it and return it to the upward-facing vessel, swallowing it into the cinnabar field—
instantly, the body becomes divine, and heaven, earth, dragons, and spirits all stand in astonishment.

Golden Duke was originally the son of the Eastern House,
yet lodged in the Western Neighbor to be born.
Recognize and summon him home to nurture,
pair him with the Maiden of Vermilion to forge kinship.
This meaning was already conveyed in the ninth verse of the previous four—
now I refrain from repeating it.
All lies within the workings and symbolic forms:
there is yang within yin, reverting to yang and then to yin again;
there is yin within yang, reverting to yin and then to yang again.
There are inner and outer medicines of yin-yang, water-fire;
inner and outer Three Essences;
inner and outer Five Phases and Four Symbols.
There are also methods of mutual interaction between inner and outer yin-yang—
endlessly shifting, beyond description.
We may silently comprehend it in the heart, but without encountering the true teaching,
none can fully fathom its depths.
The immortal elder composed this poem so that the enlightened, grasping one corner, may suffice.

All things in profusion return to their root—
returning to the root and reviving the mandate ensures everlasting existence.
To know the constant and return to the origin is rare among men;
reckless action invites misfortune, as often heard.
The scripture says: All things in profusion return to their root.
Returning to the root is called stillness; stillness is called reviving the mandate.
Reviving the mandate is called the constant; knowing the constant is called illumination.
Before a person is born, they dwell in profound obscurity, merged with primal simplicity.
At birth, they discern yin and yang, receive them from father and mother—
reversing the course, one seizes the precelestial qi as the elixir’s mother,
plunders the true qi of yin and yang as the foundation of transformation,
refines the form to reenter formlessness,
refines qi to restore it to primal simplicity,
refines spirit to unite with the Dao—
thus, returning to the root and reviving the mandate ensures everlasting existence.
Those who know the constant Way and return to their origin are sages—
hence they attain long life.
Those who do not know the constant Way are the common folk—
hence their reckless actions invite misfortune, as often heard.

The Red Dragon and Black Tiger meet east and west,
the Four Symbols intertwine at wu-ji.
Once reunited, they naturally operate—
who says the golden elixir cannot be achieved?
East is the qi of the Red Dragon’s bowstring, called the Maiden of Vermilion.
West is the qi of the Black Tiger’s bowstring, called Golden Duke.
These two are like mercury within cinnabar, silver within lead.
When the Red Dragon and Black Tiger unite the qi of the two bowstrings,
it is the Four Symbols of south, north, east, and west intertwining at wu-ji,
forming a single grain of millet.
Ingested into the cinnabar field, then guide the fire beginning with the *Fu* hexagram at the yang hour of midnight,
first advancing the yang fire.
From the *Gou* hexagram at the yin hour of noon, first advancing the yin tally.
*Fu* and *Gou* are the origins of yin and yang, marking the winter and summer solstices.
The yin tally and yang fire begin here—
drawing and adding, operating all according to method, never deviating—
who would say the Golden Mother cannot be perfected?

If you have not refined the returning elixir, refine it with haste;
once refined, you must know when to stop and be content.
If you persist with an insatiable heart,
you will inevitably suffer humiliation one day.
Time flies swiftly, and it waits for no one—
if you have not refined the returning elixir, begin at once.
Once refined, with ten months of work complete,
you must embrace the One and guard unity, maintaining fullness and defending the city—
no need for further fire.
If you do not know contentment and persist without cease,
you will instead invite calamity and disgrace.
Thus, Master Zhongli said: When the elixir ripens, do not apply fire—
if you apply fire, you will harm the elixir.
At this stage, if you can sincerely perceive your nature,
like Bodhidharma facing the wall for nine years, the Way will be achieved.

At first, through effort, people seek it;
by the time it becomes effortless, the crowd understands.
Yet they see only effortlessness as the essential Way—
how would they know that effort is the root?
Some who study the Buddha’s path of cultivating nature
cling to the notion that all effort is delusion, disparaging the Daoist path of refining life.
They know one aspect but not the other, glimpsing the gate but never ascending the hall—
how would they know that the path of refining life begins with effort,
refining the outer medicine to transform the form;
proceeds with action, refining the form to transform qi;
and ultimately attains effortless freedom—
holding to the One to recognize the heart and perceive the nature,
qi naturally returns to spirit, spirit naturally unites with the Dao,
so that form and spirit together become wondrous and unfathomable,
spirit and Dao unite in truth and formlessness.

When form has ceased to be, how can one speak of form, of action, of effort, of illusion?
How can one assert that life is not nature, or that nature is not life?
Forcibly dividing them into "nature" and "life"—when merged as one, they were never distinct.
Thus, from action to non-action, from form to formlessness, the Way reaches its ultimate—
a truth beyond the grasp of those of middling or lesser capacity.

The Immortal Elder composed this poem to admonish later students:
they see only effortlessness as the essential mystery,
yet fail to recognize that action and effort are the very root of effortlessness.

An alternate version reads:
*The trap and net in hand—none know my art.*
*Once ashore, the boat is cast aside; in ten months, one stares in vain.*
*Saints and mortals mingle in the marketplace, fish and dragons blend on the thoroughfare.*
*How vexing for the people of this world—face to face, yet never meeting.*

The method of *observing form, sealing qi, and contemplating spirit*:
at first, the path is arduous; later, it becomes smooth and unobstructed.
In an instant, one may traverse ten thousand lands—
such is the subtle clarity of the yin spirit.
Yet alas, the form remains yin, prone to decay and difficult to stabilize,
inevitably leading to rebirth through womb-seizing or body-snatching.

Those who practice *womb-seizing, body-snatching, or relocation* are called the "Four Fruits" disciples—
their cultivation pertains to the yin spirit, making them ghost-immortals, not yang-immortals.
If one can subdue the dragon and tame the tiger, refine and ingest the golden elixir,
transforming form into formlessness to become a yang-immortal,
only then does form and spirit together attain wondrousness, uniting with the Dao in truth—
never withering, how could this compare to the yin spirit?
Thus, Master Cui said:
*The numinous light departs, entering profound stillness—*
*one dies as a radiant ghost of the yin realm.*

The Buddha’s teaching urges cultivation toward the Land of Ultimate Bliss,
for that bliss is none other than the golden realm.
In truth, only this form is real—
the other two are but vain speculations.

When the Buddha taught beings to cultivate the Cold Land of Ultimate Bliss,
he referred to the image of wondrous golden hue.
In recent times, those who chant the Buddha’s name and transform beings speak of the Pure Land—
this is but a teaching for the middling and lesser,
a speck of dust for those of great root and capacity.
Little do they know that the true Land of Ultimate Bliss, the Pure Land,
lies in the West, not far at all—
there, true gold is nurtured, each grain as large as a millet seed, weighing sixteen ounces.
Thus, the Buddha is said to possess a sixteen-foot golden body.
If one can refine and ingest this true gold, one instantly transcends to the sacred realm,
transforming the formed into the formless.
When gathered, the golden form stands majestic; when dispersed, it enters into emptiness,
its transformations boundless, its movements unfathomable—
responding to conditions, pervading all, yet the true body remains quiescent, never acting.
This is the Land of Ultimate Bliss in the West.

Hence it is said: *In truth, only this form is real—*
*the other two are but vain speculations.*

The Buddha entered nirvana at the end of the Zhou dynasty;
several centuries later, during the reign of Emperor Ming of Han,
his relics were retrieved and reburied in Fengxiang.
Emperor Xianzong of Tang later unearthed a bone—
how could they have known it was the supreme Way of the Yellow Emperor ascending to heaven on a dragon?

Within the indistinct and elusive, there is an image;
within the obscure and unfathomable, there is true essence.
From this, being and non-being naturally interpenetrate—
how can one conceive of it without first perceiving it?

That within the indistinct and elusive is the *qi* of the dragon’s bowstring;
that within the obscure and unfathomable is the essence of the tiger’s bowstring.
The two bowstrings possess *qi* but no substance—
vague and elusive, obscure and unfathomable,
invisible to the eye, inaudible to the ear—
this is the true One’s *qi*, numinous yet formless.

The True One said:
*Non-being is the dragon; being is the tiger.*
*Non-being is the qi of mercury; being is the essence of lead.*
Thus, when the *qi* of the two bowstrings intertwine,
non-being, moved by being, generates numinosity;
being, stirred by non-being, takes form.
Only through the mutual interpenetration of being and non-being
does the true One’s *qi* condense into a millet grain,
suspended in the void, its radiance illuminating the sun.
How could those who sit in dull contemplation, their minds mired in dust,
ever comprehend this?

In cultivation, blend with the world and harmonize your light;
be round when round, square when square.
Concealed or manifest, yielding or resisting—none can fathom your conduct.
How then could others perceive your way of being?

Wearing coarse cloth while holding jade,
harmonizing your light with the dust,
breaking through barriers,
transcending self and other,
uniting inner and outer—
only then does one embody the immortal’s way of concealment and revelation.

---

**Five Additional Verses**

Cease all cunning and false exertions;
recognize instead the other’s deathless method.
In the flask, ever replenish the wine of life;
in the crucible, gather the nectar of returning soul.

*The Kinship of the Three* states:
*Kindred methods yield results with ease;*
*unrelated arts demand cunning labor.*
Yet many cultivators cling to unrelated, false methods,
exerting effort upon themselves while refusing to seek the other’s kindred, deathless way.
If one can extract from the crucible the yang elixir of returning to the root,
and within the abdomen ever replenish the mercury fire of life extension—
these two are the supreme treasures for refining the body.

Fortune and misfortune arise in mutual dependence,
like shadow following form, echo answering sound.
If one can reverse the mechanism of life and death,
then in the turn of a palm, calamity transforms into blessing.

Yang governs life and is called fortune;
yin governs death and is called misfortune.
As yin wanes and yang waxes, yang at its peak gives rise to yin—
mutually dependent, like shadow and echo,
this is the natural principle of the common Way.
If one can reverse this mechanism of life and death through counter-cultivation,
then in the turn of a palm, calamity becomes blessing,
harm gives birth to grace—
even a man may conceive.

Striking bamboo to summon the tortoise that swallows the jade mushroom,
Plucking the zither to call the phoenix that drinks the elixir spoon.
Of late, a golden light distinct suffuses the body—
this rule is not for common folk to speak of.

Bamboo embodies hollow-heartedness and non-attachment;
the zither holds the meaning of upright sound and harmonious resonance.
The tortoise is the Black Tiger,
the phoenix is the Red Dragon.
The Dragon’s string-qi is called the jade mushroom,
the Tiger’s child-qi is called the elixir spoon.
This speaks of Dragon and Tiger as passionless beings,
yet capable of union—thus “striking bamboo” signifies their mutual engagement.
When Dragon and Tiger unite as husband and wife in harmony,
this is called “plucking the zither.”
As Dragon and Tiger couple, the two string-qi devour each other,
refining into the golden elixir.
Light pierces the curtain,
and in that moment, gather it—
ingest it into the cinnabar field,
subduing one’s own yin mercury.
Then, with hollow heart, circulate the fire,
harmonizing yin and yang,
aligning with breath.
Through breath, direct the spirit-qi,
gathering and dispersing water and fire.
With water and fire, refine and nurture the embryonic breath,
continuously, as if ever-present—
swimming between Kan and Li,
their intercourse gives birth to the golden liquid.
Thus, when circulating the fire,
should you suddenly feel the true qi surge up the spine to the Mud Pill Palace,
trickling with sound,
as if something touches the crown of the brain—
in an instant, like sparrow’s eggs, grain by grain,
it ascends from the palate into the Tower of Multi-Storied Chambers,
cool as ice, sweet as butter, its flavor beyond compare.
If this occurs, you have attained the Way of the Golden Liquid Returning Elixir.
Gently swallow it down to the cinnabar field,
unceasingly, without interruption.
The five viscera become clear and empty,
and with eyes closed, an inner vision reveals light like a candle.
From within the five viscera, ten thousand strands of golden light emerge from the body,
like wheels of fire and clouds of mist,
spiraling to envelop the form—
radiant and wondrous,
how could it be compared to the dust-borne multitudes?

Once the monkey-heart is stilled and the mind’s mechanism is clear,
three thousand merits fulfilled, you stand equal with heaven.
Naturally, there is a crucible to refine Dragon and Tiger—
why cling to household and yearn for wife and child?
After worldly passions thicken, the Dao-heart is hard to know.
Each person bears their home and loves their wife and children,
unaware of the Way of returning to the root.
The Immortal Elder sighs in lament,
composing this to admonish those who cultivate the true.

Even if you awaken to the true suchness of nature,
you may yet cast off the body only to re-enter it.
Though you transform and refine the great medicine anew,
you transcend the leakless to become a true person.
Before the great function manifests,
before the great dharma is fully illuminated,
the slightest leakage means casting off the body to re-enter it.
But if you achieve perfect clarity and illumination,
fully refine the golden elixir,
and complete the ten stages of the Dao,
you are called a true person.

*Thirteen Western River Moon Songs*
The Immortal Elder says:
“West” is the direction of metal.
“River” is the essence of water.
“Moon” is the function of the medicine.
The inner medicine resembles the outer medicine;
inner communication requires outer communication as well.
The elixir head harmonizes similarly,
with two kinds of nurturing as its function.

The *Breaking Delusion Song* of Yi Gate says:
The Dao lies in setting up the inner furnace,
while establishing the crucible resides in the outer Way.
In the outer, Li and Kan;
mercury and lead return within.
This clarifies the two medicines, inner and outer.

The outer medicine is the golden elixir.
It is wrought in the furnace of the two eights,
completed in less than half a day.
The inner medicine is the golden liquid returning elixir.
It is wrought within one’s own body,
waiting until the tenth month is full
before the embryo can shed its shell and become a sage.

Observing the inner and outer medicines,
the harmonizing of the elixir head,
and the methods of their function—
though roughly similar,
in their application and firing times,
they are truly far apart.
When we begin our practice,
at the moment the inner and outer elixir heads harmonize,
we must guard against danger and consider risk,
not deviating by even a hair’s breadth.
Be reverent, be reverent.

Within, there is the natural true fire,
in the crucible, a blazing, enduring red.
The outer furnace requires diligent effort in increase and decrease—
nothing surpasses the wondrousness of the true seed.
Though the inner medicine possesses the true fire within the earthen crucible,
blazing enduringly red,
if it does not rely on the outer furnace’s diligent effort,
adjusting and reducing its operation without error,
it may yet avoid peril.
Yet the endless transformations of the inner and outer true fires
truly depend on the marvel of the true lead.
This treasure alone can capture mercury,
preventing its flight.
Some, not understanding this principle,
claim that the inner medicine is refined by true fire,
while the outer medicine relies on ordinary fire for increase and decrease—
like peering at the sky through a tube,
worthy of a laugh.
Little do they know that though inner and outer differ,
their function is the same—
the Dao is not two.

What is called inner and outer?
A person’s body is endowed with the essence of heaven and earth,
entrusted to yin and yang’s forging to take form.
Thus, within a single form,
essence, qi, and spirit are the foundation.
Spirit is born of qi,
qi is born of essence,
essence is born of spirit.
Yet these three are the one qi of post-heaven,
the most yin of things.
If a cultivator of the true clings to this body for refinement,
they work with nothing more than essence, qi, and spirit.
Alas, these three are one,
all born of post-heaven,
pure yin without yang—
how could they transcend the things of heaven and earth?
Thus, the Immortal Elder says: refining this alone only exhausts and weakens.

Master Zhongli says:
Tears, saliva, fluids, essence, qi, blood, and marrow—
these seven have always belonged to yin.
He also says:
Refining a single thing is solitary yin.
True Unity Master says:
Solitary yin cannot generate on its own.
The *Triple Concordance* says:
A hen laying eggs alone—
her chicks are never whole.

The sages knew that the qi of their own bodies,
born after heaven and earth,
belonged to yin things,
difficult to capture and easy to lose.
Thus, they gathered the pre-heaven one qi,
with the true yin and true yang of the two eights—
kindred things—
capturing them within a single hour,
refining them into a grain of utmost yang elixir,
called true lead.
Wrought externally, it is called the outer medicine.
With the yang elixir, one captures one’s own yin mercury,
like a cat seizing a mouse.
The yang elixir is the mother-qi of heaven and earth,
one’s own mercury is the child-qi of heaven and earth.
Using the mother-qi to subdue the child-qi—
is this not of the same kind?

This workings take place within, hence it is called the inner medicine.
The Immortal Elder says:
Only when medicine meets its kindred qi does form arise;
Only when the Way accords with the subtle and formless does it become natural.

True Unity Master says:
Before heaven and earth emerged from primordial chaos,
true lead was born of the One,
gradually giving rise to heaven and earth, yin and yang, the five phases.
The *Triple Concordance* says:
Born before heaven and earth,
majestic and supremely venerable.
All these attest to the primordial one qi of the golden elixir.

Using the primordial yang elixir to refine one’s own yin mercury,
it is transformed into pure yang.
Further aided by yin and yang, tally and fire,
through the practices of withdrawal and addition,
after ten months the work is complete:
form is transmuted into qi,
qi into spirit,
spirit merges with the Dao,
ascending into the formless,
its transformations unfathomable.
Thus it transcends heaven and earth,
stands beyond creation,
grasps and molds heaven and earth, yin and yang,
yet is not molded by them—
all through the power of the primordial one qi.
Its marvel is such,
hence it is called the peerless true seed.

How could the utmost yin of post-heaven things serve as inner medicine?
How could post-heaven vulgar cinnabar, vulgar mercury, vulgar fire, vulgar water—
impure substances of disparate kind—
serve as outer medicine?

Those who study the Dao must delve into the origin,
rejecting delusive teachings,
lest they forever fall into the three lower realms.

Seven returns: cinnabar returns to its root.
Nine reversions: golden liquid returns to truth.
Do not mistake the reckoning of *yin* and *zi* for *kun* and *shen*;
simply observe the standard of the five phases’ completion.

The nine reversions and seven returns
are none other than the generative numbers of heaven and earth and the five phases.
Heaven-one generates water, earth-six completes it.
Water resides in the north,
accumulating the true qi of *kan* yin,
forming true water—
hence it is said to “reside in six.”
Earth-two generates fire, heaven-seven completes it.
Fire returns to the south,
nurturing the true qi of *li* yang,
forming true cinnabar—
hence “seven returns: cinnabar returns to its root.”
Heaven-three generates wood, earth-eight completes it.
Wood returns to the east,
settling in the *zhen* position as mercury—
hence “eight returns.”
Earth-four generates metal, heaven-nine completes it.
Metal returns to the west,
transforming in *dui* as lead—
hence “nine reversions: the golden body returns to truth.”
Heaven-five generates earth, earth-ten completes it.
Earth resides in the center,
transforming into the elixir.
Thus we know the golden elixir is formed from nothing but metal, wood, water, fire, and earth—
hence “simply observe the standard of the five phases’ completion.”
How could the reckoning of *yin* and *zi* for *kun* and *shen*
be the nine reversions and seven returns?

It is but a single taste of mercury,
circulating,
passing through all the celestial stems.
When yin and yang qi are full, it naturally becomes spiritually efficacious—
its ingress and egress never leave the Mysterious Female.

The true one’s water,
congeals to form essence.
Essence is mercury.
The true one’s qi first transforms into water in the north,
then into cinnabar in the south,
then into mercury in the east,
then into metal in the west,
and finally into the elixir in the center.
The elixir is not born without heaven and earth,
not produced without sun and moon,
not perfected without the four seasons,
not ripened without the five phases,
not completed without the total number.
Thus it traverses all the celestial stems,
and when the numbers of yin and yang are full,
it naturally transforms and becomes spiritually efficacious.
Yet its marvelous workings and transformations,
its ingress and egress,
never depart from the two gates of the Mysterious Female—
truly the root of heaven and earth.

If you wish true lead to retain mercury,
the intimate must never part from the household minister.
Wood and metal, though separated, cannot meet without cause—
they must rely on the matchmaker’s allure.

Wood’s nature loves metal’s righteous compliance,
metal’s disposition yearns for wood’s benevolent kindness.
They devour and yet cherish each other,
only then is there conception within the void.
This speaks of the inner image.

The household minister is one’s own true qi.
One’s true qi first congeals through true metal,
while the golden elixir only gains its spiritual efficacy through one’s own mercury.
The two substances are mutually necessary,
their natures yearning for each other,
only then can they transform and become spiritually efficacious.
Hence it is said:
If you wish true lead to retain mercury,
the intimate must never part from the household minister.

Lead and elixir belong to metal and thus are external,
while one’s own mercury belongs to wood and thus is internal.
The two are separated,
unable to meet without cause—
entirely dependent on the Yellow Dame to forge the elixir.
Once ingested into the abdomen,
it pairs with one’s own mercury,
requiring the Yellow Dame’s allure.
Once the two natures are matched,
they unite in the field of yin tally and fire.
Thus wood’s nature loves metal’s righteous compliance,
and metal’s disposition yearns for wood’s benevolent kindness.
The inner and outer metal and wood,
their indolent natures devouring and yet cherishing each other,
become husband and wife,
nurturing the infant within my abdomen—
only then is there conception within the void.
This is the marvel of the Dao.

The White Tiger’s first meridian is the supreme treasure,
the Flowery Pond’s divine water is true gold.
Thus we know the source of supreme goodness runs deep—
not to be compared with ordinary medicinal substances.

The White Tiger’s first meridian is the qi of the first crescent moon,
not the celestial waters of women.
To slander the supreme Dao with the twenty-four grades of the Three Peaks
is to defame the Dao—
can the Dao be defamed?
The nine heavens cannot be ascended by mere steps.

The true one’s qi in heaven is called the one water,
in the tiger it is called the first crescent,
and when refined and nurtured in the Flowery Pond it is called divine water—
this is the supreme treasure of true gold.
It never departs from the essence of the true one,
flowing through all places,
assuming various names yet capable of creation.
The classic says:
The highest goodness is like water.
For the true one’s water is born before heaven and earth—
hence it is called the highest goodness.
Its beneficial source runs deep and far,
unlike the impure medicinal substances born after heaven and earth.

If you wish to complete the nine revolutions,
first refine the self and hold the mind.
Follow the time to gather and refine the floating and sinking,
advancing the fire while guarding against grave danger.

The nine revolutions are nine years.
After the ten-month gestation,
like Bodhidharma facing the wall,
embracing the One and practicing non-action,
one’s form and spirit both become wondrous,
merging with the Dao in truth—
this is called the great return of the nine-revolved golden liquid.
Bodhidharma’s return to the West with a single sandal
is its verification.

To achieve the nine revolutions, one must first devote ten months of effort, returning the fire to refine the self, holding the mind in accordance with the time, and circulating the fire. Guard it carefully to prevent danger, probe and adjust, extract and replenish, to stabilize the floating and sinking, and distinguish host from guest. Remain receptive and not assertive, only then can peril be avoided. Thus, the form transforms into qi, qi into spirit, spirit into emptiness, transcending into formlessness.

The Cowherd and Weaver Girl’s love is the root of the Dao; the tortoise and serpent naturally embody it. The toad and crow meet at the new moon in harmonious union, the two qi mutually supporting and revolving. All is the wondrous workings of Heaven and Earth—who can fathom this profound abyss? When yin and yang are blocked and separated, fault arises; how then can heaven endure and earth last long?

The Cowherd and Weaver Girl unite once a year; the Greater Yin and Greater Yang conjoin once a month. The tortoise and serpent coil together in mutual support—all these are the workings of the two qi of yin and yang, the very root of the true Dao. The workings of the great elixir of golden cinnabar are no different. For the true One’s qi is formless and subtle; without the union of the two and eight qi of yin and yang, how could it manifest in the shape of a millet grain? After obtaining the elixir, without the steaming fusion of yin and yang’s symbolic fire, how could the golden liquid return as the elixir?

The *Cantong Qi* says:
*"Guan guan go the ospreys,
On the islet in the river.
The modest, retiring, virtuous young lady—
For her the gentleman longs."*
The male does not dwell alone, nor the female reside in solitude. The Dark Warrior’s tortoise and serpent coil together, illustrating that the female and male inherently require each other—this is the principle, what doubt remains? All is the subtle mechanism of Heaven and Earth’s workings, the Dao of creation—who can fathom this profound abyss and reverse the course of cultivation, holding the cosmos in hand?

True One Master says: *"Solitary yin cannot generate itself; solitary yang cannot complete itself. Only through the union of female and male qi can the Dao of embryonic transformation arise."* That Heaven and Earth endure long is due to the natural Dao of yin-yang union. If heavenly qi does not descend and earthly qi does not rise, the four seasons lose their order, and the myriad things fail to grow. From this, we see that when yin and yang are blocked, fault arises—how then can Heaven and Earth endure?

The *Book of Changes* says: *"One yin, one yang—this is called the Dao."* The immortal elder repeatedly emphasizes this chapter; those deeply versed in this Dao should grasp its meaning with intuition.
